module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.AcceleratorAttributes

-- | Attributes of an accelerator.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAcceleratorAttributes</a> smart constructor.
data AcceleratorAttributes
AcceleratorAttributes' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> AcceleratorAttributes

-- | The prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs.
--   Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   s3-bucket_name//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
[$sel:flowLogsS3Prefix:AcceleratorAttributes'] :: AcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false.
--   If the value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:flowLogsEnabled:AcceleratorAttributes'] :: AcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Bool

-- | The name of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is
--   required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must
--   exist and have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator
--   permission to write to the bucket.
[$sel:flowLogsS3Bucket:AcceleratorAttributes'] :: AcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>AcceleratorAttributes</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--

-- | The prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs.

module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.ByoipCidr

-- | Information about an IP address range that is provisioned for use with
--   your AWS resources through bring your own IP address (BYOIP).
--   
--   The following describes each BYOIP <tt>State</tt> that your IP address
--   range can be in.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>PENDING_PROVISIONING</b> — You’ve submitted a request to
--   provision an IP address range but it is not yet provisioned with AWS
--   Global Accelerator.</li>
--   <li><b>READY</b> — The address range is provisioned with AWS Global
--   Accelerator and can be advertised.</li>
--   <li><b>PENDING_ADVERTISING</b> — You’ve submitted a request for AWS
--   Global Accelerator to advertise an address range but it is not yet
--   being advertised.</li>
--   <li><b>ADVERTISING</b> — The address range is being advertised by AWS
--   Global Accelerator.</li>
--   <li><b>PENDING_WITHDRAWING</b> — You’ve submitted a request to
--   withdraw an address range from being advertised but it is still being
--   advertised by AWS Global Accelerator.</li>
--   <li><b>PENDING_DEPROVISIONING</b> — You’ve submitted a request to
--   deprovision an address range from AWS Global Accelerator but it is
--   still provisioned.</li>
--   <li><b>DEPROVISIONED</b> — The address range is deprovisioned from AWS
--   Global Accelerator.</li>
--   <li><b>FAILED_PROVISION</b> — The request to provision the address
--   range from AWS Global Accelerator was not successful. Please make sure
--   that you provide all of the correct information, and try again. If the
--   request fails a second time, contact AWS support.</li>
--   <li><b>FAILED_ADVERTISING</b> — The request for AWS Global Accelerator
--   to advertise the address range was not successful. Please make sure
--   that you provide all of the correct information, and try again. If the
--   request fails a second time, contact AWS support.</li>
--   <li><b>FAILED_WITHDRAW</b> — The request to withdraw the address range
--   from advertising by AWS Global Accelerator was not successful. Please
--   make sure that you provide all of the correct information, and try
--   again. If the request fails a second time, contact AWS support.</li>
--   <li><b>FAILED_DEPROVISION</b> — The request to deprovision the address
--   range from AWS Global Accelerator was not successful. Please make sure
--   that you provide all of the correct information, and try again. If the
--   request fails a second time, contact AWS support.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newByoipCidr</a> smart constructor.
data ByoipCidr
ByoipCidr' :: Maybe ByoipCidrState -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [ByoipCidrEvent] -> ByoipCidr

-- | The state of the address pool.
[$sel:state:ByoipCidr'] :: ByoipCidr -> Maybe ByoipCidrState

-- | The address range, in CIDR notation.
[$sel:cidr:ByoipCidr'] :: ByoipCidr -> Maybe Text

-- | A history of status changes for an IP address range that you bring to
--   AWS Global Accelerator through bring your own IP address (BYOIP).
[$sel:events:ByoipCidr'] :: ByoipCidr -> Maybe [ByoipCidrEvent]

-- | Create a value of <a>ByoipCidr</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:ByoipCidr'</a>, <a>byoipCidr_state</a> - The state of
--   the address pool.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidr:ByoipCidr'</a>, <a>byoipCidr_cidr</a> - The address
--   range, in CIDR notation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:events:ByoipCidr'</a>, <a>byoipCidr_events</a> - A history of
--   status changes for an IP address range that you bring to AWS Global
--   Accelerator through bring your own IP address (BYOIP).
newByoipCidr :: ByoipCidr

-- | The state of the address pool.
byoipCidr_state :: Lens' ByoipCidr (Maybe ByoipCidrState)

-- | The address range, in CIDR notation.
byoipCidr_cidr :: Lens' ByoipCidr (Maybe Text)

-- | A history of status changes for an IP address range that you bring to
--   AWS Global Accelerator through bring your own IP address (BYOIP).
byoipCidr_events :: Lens' ByoipCidr (Maybe [ByoipCidrEvent])
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.ByoipCidr.ByoipCidr
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.ByoipCidr.ByoipCidr
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.ByoipCidr.ByoipCidr
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.ByoipCidr.ByoipCidr

module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CidrAuthorizationContext

-- | Provides authorization for Amazon to bring a specific IP address range
--   to a specific AWS account using bring your own IP addresses (BYOIP).
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring Your Own IP Addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCidrAuthorizationContext</a> smart constructor.
data CidrAuthorizationContext

[$sel:message:CidrAuthorizationContext'] :: CidrAuthorizationContext -> Text

-- | The signed authorization message for the prefix and account.

--   message for the prefix and account.

module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes

-- | Attributes of a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes</a> smart
--   constructor.
data CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes

-- | The prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs.
--   Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   DOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
[$sel:flowLogsS3Prefix:CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'] :: CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false.
--   If the value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:flowLogsEnabled:CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'] :: CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Bool

-- | The name of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is
--   required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must
--   exist and have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator
--   permission to write to the bucket.
[$sel:flowLogsS3Bucket:CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'] :: CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsS3Prefix:CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Prefix</a> - The
--   prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs.
--   Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   DOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsEnabled:CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled</a> - Indicates
--   whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false. If the
--   value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt>
--   must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsS3Bucket:CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Bucket</a> - The name
--   of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is required if
--   <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must exist and
--   have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator permission to
--   write to the bucket.
newCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes :: CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes

-- | The prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs.
--   Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   DOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Prefix :: Lens' CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false.
--   If the value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled :: Lens' CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Bool)

-- | The name of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is
--   required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must
--   exist and have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator
--   permission to write to the bucket.
customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Bucket :: Lens' CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes.CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes

module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingEndpointConfiguration

-- | The list of endpoint objects. For custom routing, this is a list of
--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet IDs.

--   constructor.

--   endpoint. For custom routing accelerators, this is the virtual private
--   cloud (VPC) subnet ID.

--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet ID.

module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration

-- | For a custom routing accelerator, sets the port range and protocol for
--   all endpoints (virtual private cloud subnets) in an endpoint group to
--   accept client traffic on.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration</a> smart
--   constructor.
data CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration
CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration' :: Natural -> Natural -> NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol -> CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration

-- | The first port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint
--   group that is associated with a custom routing accelerator.
[$sel:fromPort:CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration'] :: CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration -> Natural

-- | The last port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint group
--   that is associated with a custom routing accelerator.
[$sel:toPort:CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration'] :: CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration -> Natural

-- | The protocol for the endpoint group that is associated with a custom
--   routing accelerator. The protocol can be either TCP or UDP.
[$sel:protocols:CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration'] :: CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration -> NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol

-- | Create a value of <a>CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration</a> with
--   all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_fromPort</a> - The first
--   port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint group that is
--   associated with a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_toPort</a> - The last port,
--   inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint group that is
--   associated with a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocols:CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_protocols</a> - The protocol
--   for the endpoint group that is associated with a custom routing
--   accelerator. The protocol can be either TCP or UDP.
newCustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration :: Natural -> Natural -> NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol -> CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration

-- | The first port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint
--   group that is associated with a custom routing accelerator.
customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_fromPort :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration Natural

-- | The last port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint group
--   that is associated with a custom routing accelerator.
customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_toPort :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration Natural

-- | The protocol for the endpoint group that is associated with a custom
--   routing accelerator. The protocol can be either TCP or UDP.
customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_protocols :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration (NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration.CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointConfiguration

-- | A complex type for endpoints. A resource must be valid and active when
--   you add it as an endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEndpointConfiguration</a> smart constructor.
data EndpointConfiguration
EndpointConfiguration' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> EndpointConfiguration

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:weight:EndpointConfiguration'] :: EndpointConfiguration -> Maybe Natural

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Preserve Client IP Addresses in AWS
--   Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer
--   Guide</i>.
[$sel:clientIPPreservationEnabled:EndpointConfiguration'] :: EndpointConfiguration -> Maybe Bool

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID. A resource must be valid and active when you add
--   it as an endpoint.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
[$sel:endpointId:EndpointConfiguration'] :: EndpointConfiguration -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>EndpointConfiguration</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:weight:EndpointConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>endpointConfiguration_weight</a> - The weight associated with the
--   endpoint. When you add weights to endpoints, you configure AWS Global
--   Accelerator to route traffic based on proportions that you specify.
--   For example, you might specify endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6
--   (sum=20). The result is that 4/20 of your traffic, on average, is
--   routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is routed both to the second and
--   third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to the last endpoint. For more
--   information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientIPPreservationEnabled:EndpointConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>endpointConfiguration_clientIPPreservationEnabled</a> - Indicates
--   whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an Application
--   Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The default value
--   is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Preserve Client IP Addresses in AWS
--   Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:EndpointConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>endpointConfiguration_endpointId</a> - An ID for the endpoint. If
--   the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or Application Load Balancer,
--   this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource. If the
--   endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the Elastic IP address
--   allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is the EC2 instance ID.
--   A resource must be valid and active when you add it as an endpoint.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
newEndpointConfiguration :: EndpointConfiguration

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointConfiguration_weight :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Natural)

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Preserve Client IP Addresses in AWS
--   Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer
--   Guide</i>.
endpointConfiguration_clientIPPreservationEnabled :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Bool)

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID. A resource must be valid and active when you add
--   it as an endpoint.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
endpointConfiguration_endpointId :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointConfiguration.EndpointConfiguration
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointConfiguration.EndpointConfiguration
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointConfiguration.EndpointConfiguration
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointConfiguration.EndpointConfiguration
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointConfiguration.EndpointConfiguration
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointConfiguration.EndpointConfiguration
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointConfiguration.EndpointConfiguration


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol

instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSONKey Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Headers.ToHeader Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Log.ToLog Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Amazonka.Data.ByteString.ToByteString Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.ToText Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.FromText Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance GHC.Classes.Ord Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthCheckProtocol.HealthCheckProtocol


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthState
newtype HealthState
HealthState' :: Text -> HealthState
[fromHealthState] :: HealthState -> Text
pattern HealthState_HEALTHY :: HealthState
pattern HealthState_INITIAL :: HealthState
pattern HealthState_UNHEALTHY :: HealthState
instance Amazonka.Data.XML.ToXML Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthState.HealthState
instance Amazonka.Data.XML.FromXML Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthState.HealthState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSONKey Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthState.HealthState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthState.HealthState
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSONKey Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthState.HealthState

instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthState.HealthState
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.HealthState.HealthState


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointDescription

-- | A complex type for an endpoint. Each endpoint group can include one or
--   more endpoints, such as load balancers.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEndpointDescription</a> smart constructor.
data EndpointDescription
EndpointDescription' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe HealthState -> Maybe Text -> EndpointDescription

-- | Returns a null result.
[$sel:healthReason:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe Text

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:weight:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe Natural

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Viewing Client IP Addresses in AWS Global
--   Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:clientIPPreservationEnabled:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe Bool

-- | The health status of the endpoint.
[$sel:healthState:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe HealthState

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
[$sel:endpointId:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>EndpointDescription</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthReason:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_healthReason</a> - Returns a null result.
--   
--   <a>$sel:weight:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_weight</a> - The weight associated with the
--   endpoint. When you add weights to endpoints, you configure AWS Global
--   Accelerator to route traffic based on proportions that you specify.
--   For example, you might specify endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6
--   (sum=20). The result is that 4/20 of your traffic, on average, is
--   routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is routed both to the second and
--   third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to the last endpoint. For more
--   information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientIPPreservationEnabled:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_clientIPPreservationEnabled</a> - Indicates
--   whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an Application
--   Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The default value
--   is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Viewing Client IP Addresses in AWS Global
--   Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthState:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_healthState</a> - The health status of the
--   endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_endpointId</a> - An ID for the endpoint. If the
--   endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or Application Load Balancer, this
--   is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource. If the endpoint is
--   an Elastic IP address, this is the Elastic IP address allocation ID.
--   For Amazon EC2 instances, this is the EC2 instance ID.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
newEndpointDescription :: EndpointDescription

-- | Returns a null result.
endpointDescription_healthReason :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointDescription_weight :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Natural)

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Viewing Client IP Addresses in AWS Global
--   Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointDescription_clientIPPreservationEnabled :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Bool)

-- | The health status of the endpoint.
endpointDescription_healthState :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe HealthState)

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
endpointDescription_endpointId :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointDescription.EndpointDescription
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointDescription.EndpointDescription
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointDescription.EndpointDescription
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointDescription.EndpointDescription
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointDescription.EndpointDescription
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointDescription.EndpointDescription
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointDescription.EndpointDescription


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpAddressType

IpAddressType' :: Text -> IpAddressType
[fromIpAddressType] :: IpAddressType -> Text
pattern IpAddressType_IPV4 :: IpAddressType
instance Amazonka.Data.XML.ToXML Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpAddressType.IpAddressType
instance Amazonka.Data.XML.FromXML Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpAddressType.IpAddressType
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSONKey Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpAddressType.IpAddressType
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpAddressType.IpAddressType
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSONKey Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpAddressType.IpAddressType

instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpAddressType.IpAddressType

module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpSet

-- | A complex type for the set of IP addresses for an accelerator.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newIpSet</a> smart constructor.
data IpSet
IpSet' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> IpSet

-- | The types of IP addresses included in this IP set.
[$sel:ipFamily:IpSet'] :: IpSet -> Maybe Text

-- | The array of IP addresses in the IP address set. An IP address set can
--   have a maximum of two IP addresses.
[$sel:ipAddresses:IpSet'] :: IpSet -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Create a value of <a>IpSet</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipFamily:IpSet'</a>, <a>ipSet_ipFamily</a> - The types of IP
--   addresses included in this IP set.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddresses:IpSet'</a>, <a>ipSet_ipAddresses</a> - The array
--   of IP addresses in the IP address set. An IP address set can have a
--   maximum of two IP addresses.
newIpSet :: IpSet

-- | The types of IP addresses included in this IP set.
ipSet_ipFamily :: Lens' IpSet (Maybe Text)

-- | The array of IP addresses in the IP address set. An IP address set can
--   have a maximum of two IP addresses.
ipSet_ipAddresses :: Lens' IpSet (Maybe [Text])
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpSet.IpSet
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpSet.IpSet
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpSet.IpSet
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpSet.IpSet
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpSet.IpSet
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpSet.IpSet
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.IpSet.IpSet


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | Attributes of a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCustomRoutingAccelerator</a> smart constructor.
data CustomRoutingAccelerator
CustomRoutingAccelerator' :: Maybe CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [IpSet] -> Maybe Text -> CustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | Describes the deployment status of the accelerator.
[$sel:status:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether the accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, accelerator can be deleted.
[$sel:enabled:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe Bool

-- | The date and time that the accelerator was created.
[$sel:createdTime:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The date and time that the accelerator was last modified.
[$sel:lastModifiedTime:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The value for the address type must be IPv4.
[$sel:ipAddressType:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe IpAddressType

-- | The name of the accelerator. The name must contain only alphanumeric
--   characters or hyphens (-), and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
[$sel:name:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe Text

-- | The static IP addresses that Global Accelerator associates with the
--   accelerator.
[$sel:ipSets:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe [IpSet]

-- | The Domain Name System (DNS) name that Global Accelerator creates that
--   points to your accelerator's static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:dnsName:CustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CustomRoutingAccelerator</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_status</a> - Describes the deployment
--   status of the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enabled:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_enabled</a> - Indicates whether the
--   accelerator is enabled. The value is true or false. The default value
--   is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, accelerator can be deleted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdTime:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_createdTime</a> - The date and time that
--   the accelerator was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastModifiedTime:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_lastModifiedTime</a> - The date and time
--   that the accelerator was last modified.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_ipAddressType</a> - The value for the
--   address type must be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_name</a> - The name of the accelerator.
--   The name must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-), and
--   must not begin or end with a hyphen.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipSets:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_ipSets</a> - The static IP addresses that
--   Global Accelerator associates with the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsName:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_dnsName</a> - The Domain Name System (DNS)
--   name that Global Accelerator creates that points to your accelerator's
--   static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
newCustomRoutingAccelerator :: CustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | Describes the deployment status of the accelerator.
customRoutingAccelerator_status :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator.
customRoutingAccelerator_acceleratorArn :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether the accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, accelerator can be deleted.
customRoutingAccelerator_enabled :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe Bool)

-- | The date and time that the accelerator was created.
customRoutingAccelerator_createdTime :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The date and time that the accelerator was last modified.
customRoutingAccelerator_lastModifiedTime :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The value for the address type must be IPv4.
customRoutingAccelerator_ipAddressType :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe IpAddressType)

-- | The name of the accelerator. The name must contain only alphanumeric
--   characters or hyphens (-), and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
customRoutingAccelerator_name :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe Text)

-- | The static IP addresses that Global Accelerator associates with the
--   accelerator.
customRoutingAccelerator_ipSets :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe [IpSet])

-- | The Domain Name System (DNS) name that Global Accelerator creates that
--   points to your accelerator's static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
customRoutingAccelerator_dnsName :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAccelerator.CustomRoutingAccelerator
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAccelerator.CustomRoutingAccelerator
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAccelerator.CustomRoutingAccelerator
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAccelerator.CustomRoutingAccelerator
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAccelerator.CustomRoutingAccelerator
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAccelerator.CustomRoutingAccelerator
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingAccelerator.CustomRoutingAccelerator


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Accelerator

-- | An accelerator is a complex type that includes one or more listeners
--   that process inbound connections and then direct traffic to one or
--   more endpoint groups, each of which includes endpoints, such as load
--   balancers.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAccelerator</a> smart constructor.
data Accelerator
Accelerator' :: Maybe AcceleratorStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [IpSet] -> Maybe Text -> Accelerator

-- | Describes the deployment status of the accelerator.
[$sel:status:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe AcceleratorStatus

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether the accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, accelerator can be deleted.
[$sel:enabled:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe Bool

-- | The date and time that the accelerator was created.
[$sel:createdTime:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The date and time that the accelerator was last modified.
[$sel:lastModifiedTime:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe POSIX

-- | The value for the address type must be IPv4.
[$sel:ipAddressType:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe IpAddressType

-- | The name of the accelerator. The name must contain only alphanumeric
--   characters or hyphens (-), and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
[$sel:name:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe Text

-- | The static IP addresses that Global Accelerator associates with the
--   accelerator.
[$sel:ipSets:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe [IpSet]

-- | The Domain Name System (DNS) name that Global Accelerator creates that
--   points to your accelerator's static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:dnsName:Accelerator'] :: Accelerator -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>Accelerator</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_status</a> - Describes
--   the deployment status of the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:Accelerator'</a>,
--   <a>accelerator_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enabled:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_enabled</a> -
--   Indicates whether the accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, accelerator can be deleted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdTime:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_createdTime</a> -
--   The date and time that the accelerator was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastModifiedTime:Accelerator'</a>,
--   <a>accelerator_lastModifiedTime</a> - The date and time that the
--   accelerator was last modified.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:Accelerator'</a>,
--   <a>accelerator_ipAddressType</a> - The value for the address type must
--   be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_name</a> - The name of
--   the accelerator. The name must contain only alphanumeric characters or
--   hyphens (-), and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipSets:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_ipSets</a> - The
--   static IP addresses that Global Accelerator associates with the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsName:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_dnsName</a> - The
--   Domain Name System (DNS) name that Global Accelerator creates that
--   points to your accelerator's static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
newAccelerator :: Accelerator

-- | Describes the deployment status of the accelerator.
accelerator_status :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe AcceleratorStatus)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator.
accelerator_acceleratorArn :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether the accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, accelerator can be deleted.
accelerator_enabled :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe Bool)

-- | The date and time that the accelerator was created.
accelerator_createdTime :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The date and time that the accelerator was last modified.
accelerator_lastModifiedTime :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe UTCTime)

-- | The value for the address type must be IPv4.
accelerator_ipAddressType :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe IpAddressType)

-- | The name of the accelerator. The name must contain only alphanumeric
--   characters or hyphens (-), and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
accelerator_name :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe Text)

-- | The static IP addresses that Global Accelerator associates with the
--   accelerator.
accelerator_ipSets :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe [IpSet])

-- | The Domain Name System (DNS) name that Global Accelerator creates that
--   points to your accelerator's static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
accelerator_dnsName :: Lens' Accelerator (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Accelerator.Accelerator
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Accelerator.Accelerator
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Accelerator.Accelerator
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Accelerator.Accelerator
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Accelerator.Accelerator
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Accelerator.Accelerator
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Accelerator.Accelerator


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride

-- | Override specific listener ports used to route traffic to endpoints
--   that are part of an endpoint group. For example, you can create a port
--   override in which the listener receives user traffic on ports 80 and
--   443, but your accelerator routes that traffic to ports 1080 and 1443,
--   respectively, on the endpoints.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Port overrides</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPortOverride</a> smart constructor.
data PortOverride
PortOverride' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> PortOverride

-- | The endpoint port that you want a listener port to be mapped to. This
--   is the port on the endpoint, such as the Application Load Balancer or
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
[$sel:endpointPort:PortOverride'] :: PortOverride -> Maybe Natural

-- | The listener port that you want to map to a specific endpoint port.
--   This is the port that user traffic arrives to the Global Accelerator
--   on.
[$sel:listenerPort:PortOverride'] :: PortOverride -> Maybe Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>PortOverride</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointPort:PortOverride'</a>,
--   <a>portOverride_endpointPort</a> - The endpoint port that you want a
--   listener port to be mapped to. This is the port on the endpoint, such
--   as the Application Load Balancer or Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerPort:PortOverride'</a>,
--   <a>portOverride_listenerPort</a> - The listener port that you want to
--   map to a specific endpoint port. This is the port that user traffic
--   arrives to the Global Accelerator on.
newPortOverride :: PortOverride

-- | The endpoint port that you want a listener port to be mapped to. This
--   is the port on the endpoint, such as the Application Load Balancer or
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
portOverride_endpointPort :: Lens' PortOverride (Maybe Natural)

-- | The listener port that you want to map to a specific endpoint port.
--   This is the port that user traffic arrives to the Global Accelerator
--   on.
portOverride_listenerPort :: Lens' PortOverride (Maybe Natural)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride.PortOverride
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride.PortOverride
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride.PortOverride
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride.PortOverride
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride.PortOverride
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride.PortOverride
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride.PortOverride
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortOverride.PortOverride


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointGroup

-- | A complex type for the endpoint group. An AWS Region can have only one
--   endpoint group for a specific listener.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEndpointGroup</a> smart constructor.
data EndpointGroup
EndpointGroup' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe [PortOverride] -> Maybe [EndpointDescription] -> EndpointGroup

-- | The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a
--   healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to
--   healthy. The default value is 3.
[$sel:thresholdCount:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | If the protocol is HTTP/S, then this value provides the ping path that
--   Global Accelerator uses for the destination on the endpoints for
--   health checks. The default is slash (/).
[$sel:healthCheckPath:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Text

-- | The time—10 seconds or 30 seconds—between health checks for each
--   endpoint. The default value is 30.
[$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Text

-- | The protocol that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default value is
--   TCP.
[$sel:healthCheckProtocol:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol

-- | The AWS Region where the endpoint group is located.
[$sel:endpointGroupRegion:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Text

-- | The percentage of traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic
--   is distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
[$sel:trafficDialPercentage:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Double

-- | The port that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group.
--   
--   The default port is the port for the listener that this endpoint group
--   is associated with. If the listener port is a list, Global Accelerator
--   uses the first specified port in the list of ports.
[$sel:healthCheckPort:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | Allows you to override the destination ports used to route traffic to
--   an endpoint. Using a port override lets you to map a list of external
--   destination ports (that your users send traffic to) to a list of
--   internal destination ports that you want an application endpoint to
--   receive traffic on.
[$sel:portOverrides:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe [PortOverride]

-- | The list of endpoint objects.
[$sel:endpointDescriptions:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe [EndpointDescription]

-- | Create a value of <a>EndpointGroup</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:thresholdCount:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_thresholdCount</a> - The number of consecutive health
--   checks required to set the state of a healthy endpoint to unhealthy,
--   or to set an unhealthy endpoint to healthy. The default value is 3.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPath:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_healthCheckPath</a> - If the protocol is HTTP/S, then
--   this value provides the ping path that Global Accelerator uses for the
--   destination on the endpoints for health checks. The default is slash
--   (/).
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds</a> - The time—10 seconds
--   or 30 seconds—between health checks for each endpoint. The default
--   value is 30.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckProtocol:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol</a> - The protocol that Global
--   Accelerator uses to perform health checks on endpoints that are part
--   of this endpoint group. The default value is TCP.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupRegion:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_endpointGroupRegion</a> - The AWS Region where the
--   endpoint group is located.
--   
--   <a>$sel:trafficDialPercentage:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage</a> - The percentage of traffic
--   to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic is distributed to other
--   endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPort:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_healthCheckPort</a> - The port that Global
--   Accelerator uses to perform health checks on endpoints that are part
--   of this endpoint group.
--   
--   The default port is the port for the listener that this endpoint group
--   is associated with. If the listener port is a list, Global Accelerator
--   uses the first specified port in the list of ports.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portOverrides:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_portOverrides</a> - Allows you to override the
--   destination ports used to route traffic to an endpoint. Using a port
--   override lets you to map a list of external destination ports (that
--   your users send traffic to) to a list of internal destination ports
--   that you want an application endpoint to receive traffic on.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointDescriptions:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_endpointDescriptions</a> - The list of endpoint
--   objects.
newEndpointGroup :: EndpointGroup

-- | The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a
--   healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to
--   healthy. The default value is 3.
endpointGroup_thresholdCount :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | If the protocol is HTTP/S, then this value provides the ping path that
--   Global Accelerator uses for the destination on the endpoints for
--   health checks. The default is slash (/).
endpointGroup_healthCheckPath :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The time—10 seconds or 30 seconds—between health checks for each
--   endpoint. The default value is 30.
endpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
endpointGroup_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default value is
--   TCP.
endpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe HealthCheckProtocol)

-- | The AWS Region where the endpoint group is located.
endpointGroup_endpointGroupRegion :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The percentage of traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic
--   is distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
endpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Double)

-- | The port that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group.
--   
--   The default port is the port for the listener that this endpoint group
--   is associated with. If the listener port is a list, Global Accelerator
--   uses the first specified port in the list of ports.
endpointGroup_healthCheckPort :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | Allows you to override the destination ports used to route traffic to
--   an endpoint. Using a port override lets you to map a list of external
--   destination ports (that your users send traffic to) to a list of
--   internal destination ports that you want an application endpoint to
--   receive traffic on.
endpointGroup_portOverrides :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe [PortOverride])

-- | The list of endpoint objects.
endpointGroup_endpointDescriptions :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe [EndpointDescription])
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointGroup.EndpointGroup
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointGroup.EndpointGroup
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointGroup.EndpointGroup
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointGroup.EndpointGroup
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointGroup.EndpointGroup
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointGroup.EndpointGroup
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.EndpointGroup.EndpointGroup


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange

-- | A complex type for a range of ports for a listener.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPortRange</a> smart constructor.
data PortRange
PortRange' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> PortRange

-- | The first port in the range of ports, inclusive.
[$sel:fromPort:PortRange'] :: PortRange -> Maybe Natural

-- | The last port in the range of ports, inclusive.
[$sel:toPort:PortRange'] :: PortRange -> Maybe Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>PortRange</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:PortRange'</a>, <a>portRange_fromPort</a> - The first
--   port in the range of ports, inclusive.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:PortRange'</a>, <a>portRange_toPort</a> - The last port
--   in the range of ports, inclusive.
newPortRange :: PortRange

-- | The first port in the range of ports, inclusive.
portRange_fromPort :: Lens' PortRange (Maybe Natural)

-- | The last port in the range of ports, inclusive.
portRange_toPort :: Lens' PortRange (Maybe Natural)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange.PortRange
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange.PortRange
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange.PortRange
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange.PortRange
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange.PortRange
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange.PortRange
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange.PortRange
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.PortRange.PortRange


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingListener

-- | A complex type for a listener for a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCustomRoutingListener</a> smart constructor.
data CustomRoutingListener
CustomRoutingListener' :: Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange) -> Maybe Text -> CustomRoutingListener

-- | The port range to support for connections from clients to your
--   accelerator.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
[$sel:portRanges:CustomRoutingListener'] :: CustomRoutingListener -> Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
[$sel:listenerArn:CustomRoutingListener'] :: CustomRoutingListener -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CustomRoutingListener</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:portRanges:CustomRoutingListener'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingListener_portRanges</a> - The port range to support
--   for connections from clients to your accelerator.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerArn:CustomRoutingListener'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingListener_listenerArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the listener.
newCustomRoutingListener :: CustomRoutingListener

-- | The port range to support for connections from clients to your
--   accelerator.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
customRoutingListener_portRanges :: Lens' CustomRoutingListener (Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange))

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
customRoutingListener_listenerArn :: Lens' CustomRoutingListener (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingListener.CustomRoutingListener
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingListener.CustomRoutingListener
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingListener.CustomRoutingListener
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingListener.CustomRoutingListener
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingListener.CustomRoutingListener
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingListener.CustomRoutingListener
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.CustomRoutingListener.CustomRoutingListener


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Protocol
newtype Protocol
Protocol' :: Text -> Protocol
[fromProtocol] :: Protocol -> Text
pattern Protocol_TCP :: Protocol
pattern Protocol_UDP :: Protocol

instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Protocol.Protocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Protocol.Protocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Headers.ToHeader Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Protocol.Protocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Log.ToLog Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Protocol.Protocol

instance Amazonka.Data.Text.ToText Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Protocol.Protocol
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.FromText Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Protocol.Protocol
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Types.Protocol.Protocol
