--   for connections from clients to your accelerator.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerArn:CustomRoutingListener'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingListener_listenerArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the listener.
newCustomRoutingListener :: CustomRoutingListener

-- | The port range to support for connections from clients to your
--   accelerator.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
customRoutingListener_portRanges :: Lens' CustomRoutingListener (Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange))

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
customRoutingListener_listenerArn :: Lens' CustomRoutingListener (Maybe Text)

-- | The port mappings for a specified endpoint IP address (destination).
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newDestinationPortMapping</a> smart constructor.
data DestinationPortMapping
DestinationPortMapping' :: Maybe SocketAddress -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe [SocketAddress] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState -> DestinationPortMapping

-- | The endpoint IP address/port combination for traffic received on the
--   accelerator socket address.
[$sel:destinationSocketAddress:DestinationPortMapping'] :: DestinationPortMapping -> Maybe SocketAddress

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator that
--   you have port mappings for.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:DestinationPortMapping'] :: DestinationPortMapping -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:DestinationPortMapping'] :: DestinationPortMapping -> Maybe Text

-- | The AWS Region for the endpoint group.
[$sel:endpointGroupRegion:DestinationPortMapping'] :: DestinationPortMapping -> Maybe Text

-- | The IP address type, which must be IPv4.
[$sel:ipAddressType:DestinationPortMapping'] :: DestinationPortMapping -> Maybe IpAddressType

-- | The IP address/port combinations (sockets) that map to a given
--   destination socket address.
[$sel:acceleratorSocketAddresses:DestinationPortMapping'] :: DestinationPortMapping -> Maybe [SocketAddress]

-- | The ID for the virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet.
[$sel:endpointId:DestinationPortMapping'] :: DestinationPortMapping -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether or not a port mapping destination can receive
--   traffic. The value is either ALLOW, if traffic is allowed to the
--   destination, or DENY, if traffic is not allowed to the destination.
[$sel:destinationTrafficState:DestinationPortMapping'] :: DestinationPortMapping -> Maybe CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState

-- | Create a value of <a>DestinationPortMapping</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationSocketAddress:DestinationPortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>destinationPortMapping_destinationSocketAddress</a> - The endpoint
--   IP address/port combination for traffic received on the accelerator
--   socket address.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:DestinationPortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>destinationPortMapping_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator that you have port
--   mappings for.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:DestinationPortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>destinationPortMapping_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupRegion:DestinationPortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>destinationPortMapping_endpointGroupRegion</a> - The AWS Region for
--   the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:DestinationPortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>destinationPortMapping_ipAddressType</a> - The IP address type,
--   which must be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorSocketAddresses:DestinationPortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>destinationPortMapping_acceleratorSocketAddresses</a> - The IP
--   address/port combinations (sockets) that map to a given destination
--   socket address.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:DestinationPortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>destinationPortMapping_endpointId</a> - The ID for the virtual
--   private cloud (VPC) subnet.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationTrafficState:DestinationPortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>destinationPortMapping_destinationTrafficState</a> - Indicates
--   whether or not a port mapping destination can receive traffic. The
--   value is either ALLOW, if traffic is allowed to the destination, or
--   DENY, if traffic is not allowed to the destination.
newDestinationPortMapping :: DestinationPortMapping

-- | The endpoint IP address/port combination for traffic received on the
--   accelerator socket address.
destinationPortMapping_destinationSocketAddress :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe SocketAddress)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator that
--   you have port mappings for.
destinationPortMapping_acceleratorArn :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
destinationPortMapping_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | The AWS Region for the endpoint group.
destinationPortMapping_endpointGroupRegion :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP address type, which must be IPv4.
destinationPortMapping_ipAddressType :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe IpAddressType)

-- | The IP address/port combinations (sockets) that map to a given
--   destination socket address.
destinationPortMapping_acceleratorSocketAddresses :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe [SocketAddress])

-- | The ID for the virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet.
destinationPortMapping_endpointId :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether or not a port mapping destination can receive
--   traffic. The value is either ALLOW, if traffic is allowed to the
--   destination, or DENY, if traffic is not allowed to the destination.
destinationPortMapping_destinationTrafficState :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState)

-- | A complex type for endpoints. A resource must be valid and active when
--   you add it as an endpoint.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEndpointConfiguration</a> smart constructor.
data EndpointConfiguration
EndpointConfiguration' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> EndpointConfiguration

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:weight:EndpointConfiguration'] :: EndpointConfiguration -> Maybe Natural

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Preserve Client IP Addresses in AWS
--   Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer
--   Guide</i>.
[$sel:clientIPPreservationEnabled:EndpointConfiguration'] :: EndpointConfiguration -> Maybe Bool

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID. A resource must be valid and active when you add
--   it as an endpoint.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
[$sel:endpointId:EndpointConfiguration'] :: EndpointConfiguration -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>EndpointConfiguration</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:weight:EndpointConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>endpointConfiguration_weight</a> - The weight associated with the
--   endpoint. When you add weights to endpoints, you configure AWS Global
--   Accelerator to route traffic based on proportions that you specify.
--   For example, you might specify endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6
--   (sum=20). The result is that 4/20 of your traffic, on average, is
--   routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is routed both to the second and
--   third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to the last endpoint. For more
--   information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientIPPreservationEnabled:EndpointConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>endpointConfiguration_clientIPPreservationEnabled</a> - Indicates
--   whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an Application
--   Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The default value
--   is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Preserve Client IP Addresses in AWS
--   Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer
--   Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:EndpointConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>endpointConfiguration_endpointId</a> - An ID for the endpoint. If
--   the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or Application Load Balancer,
--   this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource. If the
--   endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the Elastic IP address
--   allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is the EC2 instance ID.
--   A resource must be valid and active when you add it as an endpoint.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
newEndpointConfiguration :: EndpointConfiguration

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointConfiguration_weight :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Natural)

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Preserve Client IP Addresses in AWS
--   Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer
--   Guide</i>.
endpointConfiguration_clientIPPreservationEnabled :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Bool)

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID. A resource must be valid and active when you add
--   it as an endpoint.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
endpointConfiguration_endpointId :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Text)

-- | A complex type for an endpoint. Each endpoint group can include one or
--   more endpoints, such as load balancers.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEndpointDescription</a> smart constructor.
data EndpointDescription
EndpointDescription' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe HealthState -> Maybe Text -> EndpointDescription

-- | Returns a null result.
[$sel:healthReason:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe Text

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:weight:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe Natural

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Viewing Client IP Addresses in AWS Global
--   Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:clientIPPreservationEnabled:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe Bool

-- | The health status of the endpoint.
[$sel:healthState:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe HealthState

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
[$sel:endpointId:EndpointDescription'] :: EndpointDescription -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>EndpointDescription</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthReason:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_healthReason</a> - Returns a null result.
--   
--   <a>$sel:weight:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_weight</a> - The weight associated with the
--   endpoint. When you add weights to endpoints, you configure AWS Global
--   Accelerator to route traffic based on proportions that you specify.
--   For example, you might specify endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6
--   (sum=20). The result is that 4/20 of your traffic, on average, is
--   routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is routed both to the second and
--   third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to the last endpoint. For more
--   information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientIPPreservationEnabled:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_clientIPPreservationEnabled</a> - Indicates
--   whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an Application
--   Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The default value
--   is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Viewing Client IP Addresses in AWS Global
--   Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthState:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_healthState</a> - The health status of the
--   endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:EndpointDescription'</a>,
--   <a>endpointDescription_endpointId</a> - An ID for the endpoint. If the
--   endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or Application Load Balancer, this
--   is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the resource. If the endpoint is
--   an Elastic IP address, this is the Elastic IP address allocation ID.
--   For Amazon EC2 instances, this is the EC2 instance ID.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
newEndpointDescription :: EndpointDescription

-- | Returns a null result.
endpointDescription_healthReason :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointDescription_weight :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Natural)

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Viewing Client IP Addresses in AWS Global
--   Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointDescription_clientIPPreservationEnabled :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Bool)

-- | The health status of the endpoint.
endpointDescription_healthState :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe HealthState)

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
endpointDescription_endpointId :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | A complex type for the endpoint group. An AWS Region can have only one
--   endpoint group for a specific listener.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newEndpointGroup</a> smart constructor.
data EndpointGroup
EndpointGroup' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Double -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe [PortOverride] -> Maybe [EndpointDescription] -> EndpointGroup

-- | The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a
--   healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to
--   healthy. The default value is 3.
[$sel:thresholdCount:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | If the protocol is HTTP/S, then this value provides the ping path that
--   Global Accelerator uses for the destination on the endpoints for
--   health checks. The default is slash (/).
[$sel:healthCheckPath:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Text

-- | The time—10 seconds or 30 seconds—between health checks for each
--   endpoint. The default value is 30.
[$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Text

-- | The protocol that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default value is
--   TCP.
[$sel:healthCheckProtocol:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol

-- | The AWS Region where the endpoint group is located.
[$sel:endpointGroupRegion:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Text

-- | The percentage of traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic
--   is distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
[$sel:trafficDialPercentage:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Double

-- | The port that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group.
--   
--   The default port is the port for the listener that this endpoint group
--   is associated with. If the listener port is a list, Global Accelerator
--   uses the first specified port in the list of ports.
[$sel:healthCheckPort:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | Allows you to override the destination ports used to route traffic to
--   an endpoint. Using a port override lets you to map a list of external
--   destination ports (that your users send traffic to) to a list of
--   internal destination ports that you want an application endpoint to
--   receive traffic on.
[$sel:portOverrides:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe [PortOverride]

-- | The list of endpoint objects.
[$sel:endpointDescriptions:EndpointGroup'] :: EndpointGroup -> Maybe [EndpointDescription]

-- | Create a value of <a>EndpointGroup</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:thresholdCount:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_thresholdCount</a> - The number of consecutive health
--   checks required to set the state of a healthy endpoint to unhealthy,
--   or to set an unhealthy endpoint to healthy. The default value is 3.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPath:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_healthCheckPath</a> - If the protocol is HTTP/S, then
--   this value provides the ping path that Global Accelerator uses for the
--   destination on the endpoints for health checks. The default is slash
--   (/).
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds</a> - The time—10 seconds
--   or 30 seconds—between health checks for each endpoint. The default
--   value is 30.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckProtocol:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol</a> - The protocol that Global
--   Accelerator uses to perform health checks on endpoints that are part
--   of this endpoint group. The default value is TCP.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupRegion:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_endpointGroupRegion</a> - The AWS Region where the
--   endpoint group is located.
--   
--   <a>$sel:trafficDialPercentage:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage</a> - The percentage of traffic
--   to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic is distributed to other
--   endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPort:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_healthCheckPort</a> - The port that Global
--   Accelerator uses to perform health checks on endpoints that are part
--   of this endpoint group.
--   
--   The default port is the port for the listener that this endpoint group
--   is associated with. If the listener port is a list, Global Accelerator
--   uses the first specified port in the list of ports.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portOverrides:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_portOverrides</a> - Allows you to override the
--   destination ports used to route traffic to an endpoint. Using a port
--   override lets you to map a list of external destination ports (that
--   your users send traffic to) to a list of internal destination ports
--   that you want an application endpoint to receive traffic on.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointDescriptions:EndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>endpointGroup_endpointDescriptions</a> - The list of endpoint
--   objects.
newEndpointGroup :: EndpointGroup

-- | The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a
--   healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to
--   healthy. The default value is 3.
endpointGroup_thresholdCount :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | If the protocol is HTTP/S, then this value provides the ping path that
--   Global Accelerator uses for the destination on the endpoints for
--   health checks. The default is slash (/).
endpointGroup_healthCheckPath :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The time—10 seconds or 30 seconds—between health checks for each
--   endpoint. The default value is 30.
endpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
endpointGroup_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default value is
--   TCP.
endpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe HealthCheckProtocol)

-- | The AWS Region where the endpoint group is located.
endpointGroup_endpointGroupRegion :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The percentage of traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic
--   is distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
endpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Double)

-- | The port that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group.
--   
--   The default port is the port for the listener that this endpoint group
--   is associated with. If the listener port is a list, Global Accelerator
--   uses the first specified port in the list of ports.
endpointGroup_healthCheckPort :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | Allows you to override the destination ports used to route traffic to
--   an endpoint. Using a port override lets you to map a list of external
--   destination ports (that your users send traffic to) to a list of
--   internal destination ports that you want an application endpoint to
--   receive traffic on.
endpointGroup_portOverrides :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe [PortOverride])

-- | The list of endpoint objects.
endpointGroup_endpointDescriptions :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe [EndpointDescription])

-- | A complex type for the set of IP addresses for an accelerator.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newIpSet</a> smart constructor.
data IpSet
IpSet' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [Text] -> IpSet

-- | The types of IP addresses included in this IP set.
[$sel:ipFamily:IpSet'] :: IpSet -> Maybe Text

-- | The array of IP addresses in the IP address set. An IP address set can
--   have a maximum of two IP addresses.
[$sel:ipAddresses:IpSet'] :: IpSet -> Maybe [Text]

-- | Create a value of <a>IpSet</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipFamily:IpSet'</a>, <a>ipSet_ipFamily</a> - The types of IP
--   addresses included in this IP set.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddresses:IpSet'</a>, <a>ipSet_ipAddresses</a> - The array
--   of IP addresses in the IP address set. An IP address set can have a
--   maximum of two IP addresses.
newIpSet :: IpSet

-- | The types of IP addresses included in this IP set.
ipSet_ipFamily :: Lens' IpSet (Maybe Text)

-- | The array of IP addresses in the IP address set. An IP address set can
--   have a maximum of two IP addresses.
ipSet_ipAddresses :: Lens' IpSet (Maybe [Text])

-- | A complex type for a listener.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newListener</a> smart constructor.
data Listener
Listener' :: Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Protocol -> Maybe ClientAffinity -> Listener

-- | The list of port ranges for the connections from clients to the
--   accelerator.
[$sel:portRanges:Listener'] :: Listener -> Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
[$sel:listenerArn:Listener'] :: Listener -> Maybe Text

-- | The protocol for the connections from clients to the accelerator.
[$sel:protocol:Listener'] :: Listener -> Maybe Protocol

-- | Client affinity lets you direct all requests from a user to the same
--   endpoint, if you have stateful applications, regardless of the port
--   and protocol of the client request. Client affinity gives you control
--   over whether to always route each client to the same specific
--   endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
[$sel:clientAffinity:Listener'] :: Listener -> Maybe ClientAffinity

-- | Create a value of <a>Listener</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:portRanges:Listener'</a>, <a>listener_portRanges</a> - The
--   list of port ranges for the connections from clients to the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerArn:Listener'</a>, <a>listener_listenerArn</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:Listener'</a>, <a>listener_protocol</a> - The
--   protocol for the connections from clients to the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientAffinity:Listener'</a>, <a>listener_clientAffinity</a> -
--   Client affinity lets you direct all requests from a user to the same
--   endpoint, if you have stateful applications, regardless of the port
--   and protocol of the client request. Client affinity gives you control
--   over whether to always route each client to the same specific
--   endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
newListener :: Listener

-- | The list of port ranges for the connections from clients to the
--   accelerator.
listener_portRanges :: Lens' Listener (Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange))

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
listener_listenerArn :: Lens' Listener (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol for the connections from clients to the accelerator.
listener_protocol :: Lens' Listener (Maybe Protocol)

-- | Client affinity lets you direct all requests from a user to the same
--   endpoint, if you have stateful applications, regardless of the port
--   and protocol of the client request. Client affinity gives you control
--   over whether to always route each client to the same specific
--   endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
listener_clientAffinity :: Lens' Listener (Maybe ClientAffinity)

-- | Returns the ports and associated IP addresses and ports of Amazon EC2
--   instances in your virtual private cloud (VPC) subnets. Custom routing
--   is a port mapping protocol in AWS Global Accelerator that statically
--   associates port ranges with VPC subnets, which allows Global
--   Accelerator to route to specific instances and ports within one or
--   more subnets.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPortMapping</a> smart constructor.
data PortMapping
PortMapping' :: Maybe SocketAddress -> Maybe (NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol) -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState -> Maybe Natural -> PortMapping

-- | The EC2 instance IP address and port number in the virtual private
--   cloud (VPC) subnet.
[$sel:destinationSocketAddress:PortMapping'] :: PortMapping -> Maybe SocketAddress

-- | The protocols supported by the endpoint group.
[$sel:protocols:PortMapping'] :: PortMapping -> Maybe (NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:PortMapping'] :: PortMapping -> Maybe Text

-- | The IP address of the VPC subnet (the subnet ID).
[$sel:endpointId:PortMapping'] :: PortMapping -> Maybe Text

-- | Indicates whether or not a port mapping destination can receive
--   traffic. The value is either ALLOW, if traffic is allowed to the
--   destination, or DENY, if traffic is not allowed to the destination.
[$sel:destinationTrafficState:PortMapping'] :: PortMapping -> Maybe CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState

-- | The accelerator port.
[$sel:acceleratorPort:PortMapping'] :: PortMapping -> Maybe Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>PortMapping</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationSocketAddress:PortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>portMapping_destinationSocketAddress</a> - The EC2 instance IP
--   address and port number in the virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocols:PortMapping'</a>, <a>portMapping_protocols</a> - The
--   protocols supported by the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:PortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>portMapping_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:PortMapping'</a>, <a>portMapping_endpointId</a> -
--   The IP address of the VPC subnet (the subnet ID).
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationTrafficState:PortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>portMapping_destinationTrafficState</a> - Indicates whether or not
--   a port mapping destination can receive traffic. The value is either
--   ALLOW, if traffic is allowed to the destination, or DENY, if traffic
--   is not allowed to the destination.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorPort:PortMapping'</a>,
--   <a>portMapping_acceleratorPort</a> - The accelerator port.
newPortMapping :: PortMapping

-- | The EC2 instance IP address and port number in the virtual private
--   cloud (VPC) subnet.
portMapping_destinationSocketAddress :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe SocketAddress)

-- | The protocols supported by the endpoint group.
portMapping_protocols :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe (NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol))

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
portMapping_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP address of the VPC subnet (the subnet ID).
portMapping_endpointId :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether or not a port mapping destination can receive
--   traffic. The value is either ALLOW, if traffic is allowed to the
--   destination, or DENY, if traffic is not allowed to the destination.
portMapping_destinationTrafficState :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState)

-- | The accelerator port.
portMapping_acceleratorPort :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe Natural)

-- | Override specific listener ports used to route traffic to endpoints
--   that are part of an endpoint group. For example, you can create a port
--   override in which the listener receives user traffic on ports 80 and
--   443, but your accelerator routes that traffic to ports 1080 and 1443,
--   respectively, on the endpoints.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Port overrides</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPortOverride</a> smart constructor.
data PortOverride
PortOverride' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> PortOverride

-- | The endpoint port that you want a listener port to be mapped to. This
--   is the port on the endpoint, such as the Application Load Balancer or
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
[$sel:endpointPort:PortOverride'] :: PortOverride -> Maybe Natural

-- | The listener port that you want to map to a specific endpoint port.
--   This is the port that user traffic arrives to the Global Accelerator
--   on.
[$sel:listenerPort:PortOverride'] :: PortOverride -> Maybe Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>PortOverride</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointPort:PortOverride'</a>,
--   <a>portOverride_endpointPort</a> - The endpoint port that you want a
--   listener port to be mapped to. This is the port on the endpoint, such
--   as the Application Load Balancer or Amazon EC2 instance.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerPort:PortOverride'</a>,
--   <a>portOverride_listenerPort</a> - The listener port that you want to
--   map to a specific endpoint port. This is the port that user traffic
--   arrives to the Global Accelerator on.
newPortOverride :: PortOverride

-- | The endpoint port that you want a listener port to be mapped to. This
--   is the port on the endpoint, such as the Application Load Balancer or
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
portOverride_endpointPort :: Lens' PortOverride (Maybe Natural)

-- | The listener port that you want to map to a specific endpoint port.
--   This is the port that user traffic arrives to the Global Accelerator
--   on.
portOverride_listenerPort :: Lens' PortOverride (Maybe Natural)

-- | A complex type for a range of ports for a listener.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPortRange</a> smart constructor.
data PortRange
PortRange' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Natural -> PortRange

-- | The first port in the range of ports, inclusive.
[$sel:fromPort:PortRange'] :: PortRange -> Maybe Natural

-- | The last port in the range of ports, inclusive.
[$sel:toPort:PortRange'] :: PortRange -> Maybe Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>PortRange</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fromPort:PortRange'</a>, <a>portRange_fromPort</a> - The first
--   port in the range of ports, inclusive.
--   
--   <a>$sel:toPort:PortRange'</a>, <a>portRange_toPort</a> - The last port
--   in the range of ports, inclusive.
newPortRange :: PortRange

-- | The first port in the range of ports, inclusive.
portRange_fromPort :: Lens' PortRange (Maybe Natural)

-- | The last port in the range of ports, inclusive.
portRange_toPort :: Lens' PortRange (Maybe Natural)

-- | An IP address/port combination.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSocketAddress</a> smart constructor.
data SocketAddress
SocketAddress' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> SocketAddress

-- | The IP address for the socket address.
[$sel:ipAddress:SocketAddress'] :: SocketAddress -> Maybe Text

-- | The port for the socket address.
[$sel:port:SocketAddress'] :: SocketAddress -> Maybe Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>SocketAddress</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddress:SocketAddress'</a>, <a>socketAddress_ipAddress</a> -
--   The IP address for the socket address.
--   
--   <a>$sel:port:SocketAddress'</a>, <a>socketAddress_port</a> - The port
--   for the socket address.
newSocketAddress :: SocketAddress

-- | The IP address for the socket address.
socketAddress_ipAddress :: Lens' SocketAddress (Maybe Text)

-- | The port for the socket address.
socketAddress_port :: Lens' SocketAddress (Maybe Natural)

-- | A complex type that contains a <tt>Tag</tt> key and <tt>Tag</tt>
--   value.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTag</a> smart constructor.
data Tag
Tag' :: Text -> Text -> Tag

-- | A string that contains a <tt>Tag</tt> key.
[$sel:key:Tag'] :: Tag -> Text

-- | A string that contains a <tt>Tag</tt> value.
[$sel:value:Tag'] :: Tag -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>Tag</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:key:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_key</a> - A string that contains a
--   <tt>Tag</tt> key.
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:Tag'</a>, <a>tag_value</a> - A string that contains a
--   <tt>Tag</tt> value.
newTag :: Text -> Text -> Tag

-- | A string that contains a <tt>Tag</tt> key.
tag_key :: Lens' Tag Text

-- | A string that contains a <tt>Tag</tt> value.
tag_value :: Lens' Tag Text

-- | Remove endpoints from a custom routing accelerator.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints

data RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints
RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints' :: [Text] -> Text -> RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints

-- | The IDs for the endpoints. For custom routing accelerators, endpoint
--   IDs are the virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet IDs.
[$sel:endpointIds:RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints'] :: RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints -> [Text]

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group to remove
--   endpoints from.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints'] :: RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints -> Text

--   optional fields omitted.

--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   <a>removeCustomRoutingEndpoints_endpointIds</a> - The IDs for the
--   endpoints. For custom routing accelerators, endpoint IDs are the
--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet IDs.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints'</a>,
--   <a>removeCustomRoutingEndpoints_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group to remove endpoints from.
newRemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints :: Text -> RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints

--   IDs are the virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet IDs.
removeCustomRoutingEndpoints_endpointIds :: Lens' RemoveCustomRoutingEndpoints [Text]

--   endpoints from.

-- | Provisions an IP address range to use with your AWS resources through
--   bring your own IP addresses (BYOIP) and creates a corresponding
--   address pool. After the address range is provisioned, it is ready to
--   be advertised using <a>AdvertiseByoipCidr</a>.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring Your Own IP Addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.ProvisionByoipCidr

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newProvisionByoipCidr</a> smart constructor.
data ProvisionByoipCidr
ProvisionByoipCidr' :: Text -> CidrAuthorizationContext -> ProvisionByoipCidr

-- | The public IPv4 address range, in CIDR notation. The most specific IP
--   prefix that you can specify is /24. The address range cannot overlap
--   with another address range that you've brought to this or another
--   Region.
[$sel:cidr:ProvisionByoipCidr'] :: ProvisionByoipCidr -> Text

-- | A signed document that proves that you are authorized to bring the
--   specified IP address range to Amazon using BYOIP.
[$sel:cidrAuthorizationContext:ProvisionByoipCidr'] :: ProvisionByoipCidr -> CidrAuthorizationContext

-- | Create a value of <a>ProvisionByoipCidr</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidr:ProvisionByoipCidr'</a>, <a>provisionByoipCidr_cidr</a> -
--   The public IPv4 address range, in CIDR notation. The most specific IP
--   prefix that you can specify is /24. The address range cannot overlap
--   with another address range that you've brought to this or another
--   Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidrAuthorizationContext:ProvisionByoipCidr'</a>,
--   <a>provisionByoipCidr_cidrAuthorizationContext</a> - A signed document
--   that proves that you are authorized to bring the specified IP address
--   range to Amazon using BYOIP.
newProvisionByoipCidr :: Text -> CidrAuthorizationContext -> ProvisionByoipCidr

-- | The public IPv4 address range, in CIDR notation. The most specific IP
--   prefix that you can specify is /24. The address range cannot overlap
--   with another address range that you've brought to this or another
--   Region.
provisionByoipCidr_cidr :: Lens' ProvisionByoipCidr Text

-- | A signed document that proves that you are authorized to bring the
--   specified IP address range to Amazon using BYOIP.
provisionByoipCidr_cidrAuthorizationContext :: Lens' ProvisionByoipCidr CidrAuthorizationContext

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newProvisionByoipCidrResponse</a> smart constructor.
data ProvisionByoipCidrResponse
ProvisionByoipCidrResponse' :: Maybe ByoipCidr -> Int -> ProvisionByoipCidrResponse

-- | Information about the address range.
[$sel:byoipCidr:ProvisionByoipCidrResponse'] :: ProvisionByoipCidrResponse -> Maybe ByoipCidr

[$sel:httpStatus:ProvisionByoipCidrResponse'] :: ProvisionByoipCidrResponse -> Int

--   fields omitted.
--

--   address range.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:ProvisionByoipCidrResponse'</a>,
--   <a>provisionByoipCidrResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newProvisionByoipCidrResponse :: Int -> ProvisionByoipCidrResponse

provisionByoipCidrResponse_byoipCidr :: Lens' ProvisionByoipCidrResponse (Maybe ByoipCidr)

-- | List the listeners for an accelerator.
--   
--   This operation returns paginated results.

-- | List the port mappings for a specific EC2 instance (destination) in a
--   VPC subnet endpoint. The response is the mappings for one destination
--   IP address. This is useful when your subnet endpoint has mappings that
--   span multiple custom routing accelerators in your account, or for
--   scenarios where you only want to list the port mappings for a specific
--   destination instance.
--   
--   This operation returns paginated results.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination</a> smart
--   constructor.
data ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination

-- | The token for the next set of results. You receive this token from a
--   previous call.
[$sel:nextToken:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination -> Maybe Text

-- | The number of destination port mappings that you want to return with
--   this call. The default value is 10.
[$sel:maxResults:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination -> Maybe Natural

-- | The ID for the virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet.
[$sel:endpointId:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination -> Text

-- | The endpoint IP address in a virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet for
--   which you want to receive back port mappings.
[$sel:destinationAddress:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination -> Text

instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination.ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsByDestination


-- | Provides a complete mapping from the public accelerator IP address and
--   port to destination EC2 instance IP addresses and ports in the virtual
--   public cloud (VPC) subnet endpoint for a custom routing accelerator.
--   For each subnet endpoint that you add, Global Accelerator creates a
--   new static port mapping for the accelerator. The port mappings don't
--   change after Global Accelerator generates them, so you can retrieve
--   and cache the full mapping on your servers.
--   
--   If you remove a subnet from your accelerator, Global Accelerator
--   removes (reclaims) the port mappings. If you add a subnet to your
--   accelerator, Global Accelerator creates new port mappings (the
--   existing ones don't change). If you add or remove EC2 instances in
--   your subnet, the port mappings don't change, because the mappings are
--   created when you add the subnet to Global Accelerator.
--   
--   The mappings also include a flag for each destination denoting which
--   destination IP addresses and ports are allowed or denied traffic.
--   
--   This operation returns paginated results.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.ListCustomRoutingPortMappings

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newListCustomRoutingPortMappings</a> smart constructor.
data ListCustomRoutingPortMappings
ListCustomRoutingPortMappings' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Text -> ListCustomRoutingPortMappings

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group to list the
--   custom routing port mappings for.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappings -> Maybe Text

-- | The token for the next set of results. You receive this token from a
--   previous call.
[$sel:nextToken:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappings -> Maybe Text

-- | The number of destination port mappings that you want to return with
--   this call. The default value is 10.
[$sel:maxResults:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappings -> Maybe Natural

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator to list the custom
--   routing port mappings for.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappings -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>ListCustomRoutingPortMappings</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'</a>,
--   <a>listCustomRoutingPortMappings_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group to list the custom routing
--   port mappings for.
--   
--   <a>$sel:nextToken:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'</a>,
--   <a>listCustomRoutingPortMappings_nextToken</a> - The token for the
--   next set of results. You receive this token from a previous call.
--   
--   <a>$sel:maxResults:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'</a>,
--   <a>listCustomRoutingPortMappings_maxResults</a> - The number of
--   destination port mappings that you want to return with this call. The
--   default value is 10.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'</a>,
--   <a>listCustomRoutingPortMappings_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator to list the custom routing port
--   mappings for.
newListCustomRoutingPortMappings :: Text -> ListCustomRoutingPortMappings

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group to list the
--   custom routing port mappings for.
listCustomRoutingPortMappings_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' ListCustomRoutingPortMappings (Maybe Text)

-- | The token for the next set of results. You receive this token from a
--   previous call.
listCustomRoutingPortMappings_nextToken :: Lens' ListCustomRoutingPortMappings (Maybe Text)

-- | The number of destination port mappings that you want to return with
--   this call. The default value is 10.
listCustomRoutingPortMappings_maxResults :: Lens' ListCustomRoutingPortMappings (Maybe Natural)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator to list the custom
--   routing port mappings for.
listCustomRoutingPortMappings_acceleratorArn :: Lens' ListCustomRoutingPortMappings Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.
data ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse
ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse' :: Maybe [PortMapping] -> Maybe Text -> Int -> ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse

-- | The port mappings for a custom routing accelerator.
[$sel:portMappings:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse -> Maybe [PortMapping]

-- | The token for the next set of results. You receive this token from a
--   previous call.
[$sel:nextToken:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse -> Maybe Text

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse'] :: ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse</a> with
--   all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:portMappings:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse'</a>,
--   <a>listCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse_portMappings</a> - The port
--   mappings for a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:nextToken:ListCustomRoutingPortMappings'</a>,
--   <a>listCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse_nextToken</a> - The token for
--   the next set of results. You receive this token from a previous call.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:ListCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse'</a>,
--   <a>listCustomRoutingPortMappingsResponse_httpStatus</a> - The
--   response's http status code.

--   
--   This operation returns paginated results.

data ListAccelerators

--   previous call.

-- | Create a value of <a>ListAccelerators</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--

--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:nextToken:ListAccelerators'</a>,
--   <a>listAccelerators_nextToken</a> - The token for the next set of
--   results. You receive this token from a previous call.

--   <a>$sel:maxResults:ListAccelerators'</a>,
--   <a>listAccelerators_maxResults</a> - The number of Global Accelerator
--   objects that you want to return with this call. The default value is
--   10.

--   previous call.

-- | Releases the specified address range that you provisioned to use with
--   your AWS resources through bring your own IP addresses (BYOIP) and
--   deletes the corresponding address pool.
--   
--   Before you can release an address range, you must stop advertising it
--   by using <a>WithdrawByoipCidr</a> and you must not have any
--   accelerators that are using static IP addresses allocated from its
--   address range.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring Your Own IP Addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.DeprovisionByoipCidr

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeprovisionByoipCidr</a> smart constructor.
data DeprovisionByoipCidr
DeprovisionByoipCidr' :: Text -> DeprovisionByoipCidr

-- | The address range, in CIDR notation. The prefix must be the same
--   prefix that you specified when you provisioned the address range.
[$sel:cidr:DeprovisionByoipCidr'] :: DeprovisionByoipCidr -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DeprovisionByoipCidr</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   you provisioned the address range.

-- | Specify the Amazon EC2 instance (destination) IP addresses and ports
--   for a VPC subnet endpoint that cannot receive traffic for a custom
--   routing accelerator. You can deny traffic to all destinations in the
--   VPC endpoint, or deny traffic to a specified list of destination IP
--   addresses and ports. Note that you cannot specify IP addresses or
--   ports outside of the range that you configured for the endpoint group.
--   
--   After you make changes, you can verify that the updates are complete
--   by checking the status of your accelerator: the status changes from
--   IN_PROGRESS to DEPLOYED.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.DenyCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDenyCustomRoutingTraffic</a> smart constructor.
data DenyCustomRoutingTraffic
DenyCustomRoutingTraffic' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Natural] -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> Text -> DenyCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | A list of specific Amazon EC2 instance IP addresses (destination
--   addresses) in a subnet that you want to prevent from receiving
--   traffic. The IP addresses must be a subset of the IP addresses allowed
--   for the VPC subnet associated with the endpoint group.
[$sel:destinationAddresses:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: DenyCustomRoutingTraffic -> Maybe [Text]

-- | A list of specific Amazon EC2 instance ports (destination ports) in a
--   subnet endpoint that you want to prevent from receiving traffic.
[$sel:destinationPorts:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: DenyCustomRoutingTraffic -> Maybe [Natural]

-- | Indicates whether all destination IP addresses and ports for a
--   specified VPC subnet endpoint <i>cannot</i> receive traffic from a
--   custom routing accelerator. The value is TRUE or FALSE.
--   
--   When set to TRUE, <i>no</i> destinations in the custom routing VPC
--   subnet can receive traffic. Note that you cannot specify destination
--   IP addresses and ports when the value is set to TRUE.
--   
--   When set to FALSE (or not specified), you <i>must</i> specify a list
--   of destination IP addresses that cannot receive traffic. A list of
--   ports is optional. If you don't specify a list of ports, the ports
--   that can accept traffic is the same as the ports configured for the
--   endpoint group.
--   
--   The default value is FALSE.
[$sel:denyAllTrafficToEndpoint:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: DenyCustomRoutingTraffic -> Maybe Bool

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: DenyCustomRoutingTraffic -> Text

-- | An ID for the endpoint. For custom routing accelerators, this is the
--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet ID.
[$sel:endpointId:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: DenyCustomRoutingTraffic -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DenyCustomRoutingTraffic</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationAddresses:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationAddresses</a> - A list of
--   specific Amazon EC2 instance IP addresses (destination addresses) in a
--   subnet that you want to prevent from receiving traffic. The IP
--   addresses must be a subset of the IP addresses allowed for the VPC
--   subnet associated with the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationPorts:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationPorts</a> - A list of specific
--   Amazon EC2 instance ports (destination ports) in a subnet endpoint
--   that you want to prevent from receiving traffic.
--   
--   <a>$sel:denyAllTrafficToEndpoint:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_denyAllTrafficToEndpoint</a> - Indicates
--   whether all destination IP addresses and ports for a specified VPC
--   subnet endpoint <i>cannot</i> receive traffic from a custom routing
--   accelerator. The value is TRUE or FALSE.
--   
--   When set to TRUE, <i>no</i> destinations in the custom routing VPC
--   subnet can receive traffic. Note that you cannot specify destination
--   IP addresses and ports when the value is set to TRUE.
--   
--   When set to FALSE (or not specified), you <i>must</i> specify a list
--   of destination IP addresses that cannot receive traffic. A list of
--   ports is optional. If you don't specify a list of ports, the ports
--   that can accept traffic is the same as the ports configured for the
--   endpoint group.
--   
--   The default value is FALSE.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointId</a> - An ID for the endpoint.
--   For custom routing accelerators, this is the virtual private cloud
--   (VPC) subnet ID.
newDenyCustomRoutingTraffic :: Text -> Text -> DenyCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | A list of specific Amazon EC2 instance IP addresses (destination
--   addresses) in a subnet that you want to prevent from receiving
--   traffic. The IP addresses must be a subset of the IP addresses allowed
--   for the VPC subnet associated with the endpoint group.
denyCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationAddresses :: Lens' DenyCustomRoutingTraffic (Maybe [Text])

-- | A list of specific Amazon EC2 instance ports (destination ports) in a
--   subnet endpoint that you want to prevent from receiving traffic.
denyCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationPorts :: Lens' DenyCustomRoutingTraffic (Maybe [Natural])

-- | Indicates whether all destination IP addresses and ports for a
--   specified VPC subnet endpoint <i>cannot</i> receive traffic from a
--   custom routing accelerator. The value is TRUE or FALSE.
--   
--   When set to TRUE, <i>no</i> destinations in the custom routing VPC
--   subnet can receive traffic. Note that you cannot specify destination
--   IP addresses and ports when the value is set to TRUE.
--   
--   When set to FALSE (or not specified), you <i>must</i> specify a list
--   of destination IP addresses that cannot receive traffic. A list of
--   ports is optional. If you don't specify a list of ports, the ports
--   that can accept traffic is the same as the ports configured for the
--   endpoint group.
--   
--   The default value is FALSE.
denyCustomRoutingTraffic_denyAllTrafficToEndpoint :: Lens' DenyCustomRoutingTraffic (Maybe Bool)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
denyCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' DenyCustomRoutingTraffic Text

-- | An ID for the endpoint. For custom routing accelerators, this is the
--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet ID.
denyCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointId :: Lens' DenyCustomRoutingTraffic Text

instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.DenyCustomRoutingTraffic.DenyCustomRoutingTraffic


-- | Delete a listener from an accelerator.

instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.DeleteCustomRoutingEndpointGroup.DeleteCustomRoutingEndpointGroup


-- | Delete a custom routing accelerator. Before you can delete an
--   accelerator, you must disable it and remove all dependent resources
--   (listeners and endpoint groups). To disable the accelerator, update
--   the accelerator to set <tt>Enabled</tt> to false.
--   
--   When you create a custom routing accelerator, by default, Global
--   Accelerator provides you with a set of two static IP addresses.
--   
--   The IP addresses are assigned to your accelerator for as long as it
--   exists, even if you disable the accelerator and it no longer accepts
--   or routes traffic. However, when you <i>delete</i> an accelerator, you
--   lose the static IP addresses that are assigned to the accelerator, so
--   you can no longer route traffic by using them. As a best practice,
--   ensure that you have permissions in place to avoid inadvertently
--   deleting accelerators. You can use IAM policies with Global
--   Accelerator to limit the users who have permissions to delete an
--   accelerator. For more information, see <a>Authentication and Access
--   Control</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator</a> smart
--   constructor.
data DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator
DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator' :: Text -> DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator to
--   delete.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>deleteCustomRoutingAccelerator_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator to delete.

--   delete.
deleteCustomRoutingAccelerator_acceleratorArn :: Lens' DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator Text

instance Amazonka.Data.Path.ToPath Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator.DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator
instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator.DeleteCustomRoutingAccelerator


-- | Delete an accelerator. Before you can delete an accelerator, you must
--   disable it and remove all dependent resources (listeners and endpoint
--   groups). To disable the accelerator, update the accelerator to set
--   <tt>Enabled</tt> to false.
--   
--   When you create an accelerator, by default, Global Accelerator
--   provides you with a set of two static IP addresses. Alternatively, you
--   can bring your own IP address ranges to Global Accelerator and assign
--   IP addresses from those ranges.
--   
--   The IP addresses are assigned to your accelerator for as long as it
--   exists, even if you disable the accelerator and it no longer accepts
--   or routes traffic. However, when you <i>delete</i> an accelerator, you
--   lose the static IP addresses that are assigned to the accelerator, so
--   you can no longer route traffic by using them. As a best practice,
--   ensure that you have permissions in place to avoid inadvertently
--   deleting accelerators. You can use IAM policies with Global
--   Accelerator to limit the users who have permissions to delete an
--   accelerator. For more information, see <a>Authentication and Access
--   Control</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.DeleteAccelerator

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDeleteAccelerator</a> smart constructor.
data DeleteAccelerator
DeleteAccelerator' :: Text -> DeleteAccelerator

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of an accelerator.

--   omitted.

-- | Create a listener to process inbound connections from clients to an
--   accelerator. Connections arrive to assigned static IP addresses on a
--   port, port range, or list of port ranges that you specify.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.CreateListener

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateListener</a> smart constructor.
data CreateListener
CreateListener' :: Maybe ClientAffinity -> Text -> NonEmpty PortRange -> Protocol -> Text -> CreateListener

-- | Client affinity lets you direct all requests from a user to the same
--   endpoint, if you have stateful applications, regardless of the port
--   and protocol of the client request. Client affinity gives you control
--   over whether to always route each client to the same specific
--   endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
[$sel:clientAffinity:CreateListener'] :: CreateListener -> Maybe ClientAffinity

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of your accelerator.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:CreateListener'] :: CreateListener -> Text

-- | The list of port ranges to support for connections from clients to
--   your accelerator.
[$sel:portRanges:CreateListener'] :: CreateListener -> NonEmpty PortRange

-- | The protocol for connections from clients to your accelerator.
[$sel:protocol:CreateListener'] :: CreateListener -> Protocol

-- | A unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the
--   idempotency—that is, the uniqueness—of the request.
[$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateListener'] :: CreateListener -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateListener</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientAffinity:CreateListener'</a>,
--   <a>createListener_clientAffinity</a> - Client affinity lets you direct
--   all requests from a user to the same endpoint, if you have stateful
--   applications, regardless of the port and protocol of the client
--   request. Client affinity gives you control over whether to always
--   route each client to the same specific endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:CreateListener'</a>,
--   <a>createListener_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of your accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portRanges:CreateListener'</a>,
--   <a>createListener_portRanges</a> - The list of port ranges to support
--   for connections from clients to your accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:CreateListener'</a>, <a>createListener_protocol</a> -
--   The protocol for connections from clients to your accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateListener'</a>,
--   <a>createListener_idempotencyToken</a> - A unique, case-sensitive
--   identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency—that is, the
--   uniqueness—of the request.
newCreateListener :: Text -> NonEmpty PortRange -> Protocol -> Text -> CreateListener

-- | Client affinity lets you direct all requests from a user to the same
--   endpoint, if you have stateful applications, regardless of the port
--   and protocol of the client request. Client affinity gives you control
--   over whether to always route each client to the same specific
--   endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
createListener_clientAffinity :: Lens' CreateListener (Maybe ClientAffinity)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of your accelerator.
createListener_acceleratorArn :: Lens' CreateListener Text

-- | The list of port ranges to support for connections from clients to
--   your accelerator.
createListener_portRanges :: Lens' CreateListener (NonEmpty PortRange)

-- | The protocol for connections from clients to your accelerator.
createListener_protocol :: Lens' CreateListener Protocol

-- | A unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the
--   idempotency—that is, the uniqueness—of the request.
createListener_idempotencyToken :: Lens' CreateListener Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateListenerResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CreateListenerResponse
CreateListenerResponse' :: Maybe Listener -> Int -> CreateListenerResponse

-- | The listener that you've created.
[$sel:listener:CreateListenerResponse'] :: CreateListenerResponse -> Maybe Listener

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:CreateListenerResponse'] :: CreateListenerResponse -> Int
