-- | Create an endpoint group for the specified listener. An endpoint group
--   is a collection of endpoints in one AWS Region. A resource must be
--   valid and active when you add it as an endpoint.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.CreateEndpointGroup

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateEndpointGroup</a> smart constructor.
data CreateEndpointGroup
CreateEndpointGroup' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol -> Maybe Double -> Maybe [EndpointConfiguration] -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe [PortOverride] -> Text -> Text -> Text -> CreateEndpointGroup

-- | The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a
--   healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to
--   healthy. The default value is 3.
[$sel:thresholdCount:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | If the protocol is HTTP/S, then this specifies the path that is the
--   destination for health check targets. The default value is slash (/).
[$sel:healthCheckPath:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Text

-- | The time—10 seconds or 30 seconds—between each health check for an
--   endpoint. The default value is 30.
[$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | The protocol that AWS Global Accelerator uses to check the health of
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default value is
--   TCP.
[$sel:healthCheckProtocol:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol

-- | The percentage of traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic
--   is distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
[$sel:trafficDialPercentage:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Double

-- | The list of endpoint objects.
[$sel:endpointConfigurations:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Maybe [EndpointConfiguration]

-- | The port that AWS Global Accelerator uses to check the health of
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default port is
--   the listener port that this endpoint group is associated with. If
--   listener port is a list of ports, Global Accelerator uses the first
--   port in the list.
[$sel:healthCheckPort:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | Override specific listener ports used to route traffic to endpoints
--   that are part of this endpoint group. For example, you can create a
--   port override in which the listener receives user traffic on ports 80
--   and 443, but your accelerator routes that traffic to ports 1080 and
--   1443, respectively, on the endpoints.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Port overrides</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:portOverrides:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Maybe [PortOverride]

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
[$sel:listenerArn:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Text

-- | The AWS Region where the endpoint group is located. A listener can
--   have only one endpoint group in a specific Region.
[$sel:endpointGroupRegion:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Text

-- | A unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the
--   idempotency—that is, the uniqueness—of the request.
[$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateEndpointGroup'] :: CreateEndpointGroup -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateEndpointGroup</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.

-- | Create a listener to process inbound connections from clients to a
--   custom routing accelerator. Connections arrive to assigned static IP
--   addresses on the port range that you specify.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.CreateCustomRoutingListener

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateCustomRoutingListener</a> smart constructor.

--   listener.

--   accelerator.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.

-- | Create an endpoint group for the specified listener for a custom
--   routing accelerator. An endpoint group is a collection of endpoints in
--   one AWS Region.

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup</a> smart
--   constructor.

--   endpoint.

--   cloud subnets) in a custom routing endpoint group to accept client
--   traffic on.

-- | Create a custom routing accelerator. A custom routing accelerator
--   directs traffic to one of possibly thousands of Amazon EC2 instance
--   destinations running in a single or multiple virtual private clouds
--   (VPC) subnet endpoints.
--   
--   Be aware that, by default, all destination EC2 instances in a VPC
--   subnet endpoint cannot receive traffic. To enable all destinations to
--   receive traffic, or to specify individual port mappings that can
--   receive traffic, see the <a>AllowCustomRoutingTraffic</a> operation.
--   
--   Global Accelerator is a global service that supports endpoints in
--   multiple AWS Regions but you must specify the US West (Oregon) Region
--   to create or update accelerators.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateCustomRoutingAccelerator</a> smart
--   constructor.
data CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator
CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe [Text] -> Text -> Text -> CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | Indicates whether an accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, an accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
[$sel:enabled:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe Bool

-- | The value for the address type must be IPv4.
[$sel:ipAddressType:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe IpAddressType

-- | Create tags for an accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Tagging in AWS Global Accelerator</a> in
--   the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:tags:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe [Tag]

-- | Optionally, if you've added your own IP address pool to Global
--   Accelerator (BYOIP), you can choose IP addresses from your own pool to
--   use for the accelerator's static IP addresses when you create an
--   accelerator. You can specify one or two addresses, separated by a
--   space. Do not include the /32 suffix.
--   
--   Only one IP address from each of your IP address ranges can be used
--   for each accelerator. If you specify only one IP address from your IP
--   address range, Global Accelerator assigns a second static IP address
--   for the accelerator from the AWS IP address pool.
--   
--   Note that you can't update IP addresses for an existing accelerator.
--   To change them, you must create a new accelerator with the new
--   addresses.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring your own IP addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:ipAddresses:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The name of a custom routing accelerator. The name can have a maximum
--   of 64 characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens
--   (-), and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
[$sel:name:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Text

-- | A unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the
--   idempotency—that is, the uniqueness—of the request.
[$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Text

--   optional fields omitted.

--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.

--   the address type must be IPv4.

-- | Create an accelerator. An accelerator includes one or more listeners
--   that process inbound connections and direct traffic to one or more
--   endpoint groups, each of which includes endpoints, such as Network
--   Load Balancers.
--   
--   Global Accelerator is a global service that supports endpoints in
--   multiple AWS Regions but you must specify the US West (Oregon) Region
--   to create or update accelerators.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.CreateAccelerator

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateAccelerator</a> smart constructor.
data CreateAccelerator
CreateAccelerator' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe [Text] -> Text -> Text -> CreateAccelerator

-- | Indicates whether an accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, an accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
[$sel:enabled:CreateAccelerator'] :: CreateAccelerator -> Maybe Bool

-- | The value for the address type must be IPv4.
[$sel:ipAddressType:CreateAccelerator'] :: CreateAccelerator -> Maybe IpAddressType

-- | Create tags for an accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Tagging in AWS Global Accelerator</a> in
--   the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:tags:CreateAccelerator'] :: CreateAccelerator -> Maybe [Tag]

-- | Optionally, if you've added your own IP address pool to Global
--   Accelerator (BYOIP), you can choose IP addresses from your own pool to
--   use for the accelerator's static IP addresses when you create an
--   accelerator. You can specify one or two addresses, separated by a
--   space. Do not include the /32 suffix.
--   
--   Only one IP address from each of your IP address ranges can be used
--   for each accelerator. If you specify only one IP address from your IP
--   address range, Global Accelerator assigns a second static IP address
--   for the accelerator from the AWS IP address pool.
--   
--   Note that you can't update IP addresses for an existing accelerator.
--   To change them, you must create a new accelerator with the new
--   addresses.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring Your Own IP Addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:ipAddresses:CreateAccelerator'] :: CreateAccelerator -> Maybe [Text]

-- | The name of an accelerator. The name can have a maximum of 32
--   characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-),
--   and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
[$sel:name:CreateAccelerator'] :: CreateAccelerator -> Text

-- | A unique, case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the
--   idempotency—that is, the uniqueness—of an accelerator.
[$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateAccelerator'] :: CreateAccelerator -> Text

-- | Specify the Amazon EC2 instance (destination) IP addresses and ports
--   for a VPC subnet endpoint that can receive traffic for a custom
--   routing accelerator. You can allow traffic to all destinations in the
--   subnet endpoint, or allow traffic to a specified list of destination
--   IP addresses and ports in the subnet. Note that you cannot specify IP
--   addresses or ports outside of the range that you configured for the
--   endpoint group.
--   
--   After you make changes, you can verify that the updates are complete
--   by checking the status of your accelerator: the status changes from
--   IN_PROGRESS to DEPLOYED.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.AllowCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAllowCustomRoutingTraffic</a> smart constructor.
data AllowCustomRoutingTraffic
AllowCustomRoutingTraffic' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Natural] -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> Text -> AllowCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | A list of specific Amazon EC2 instance IP addresses (destination
--   addresses) in a subnet that you want to allow to receive traffic. The
--   IP addresses must be a subset of the IP addresses that you specified
--   for the endpoint group.
--   
--   <tt>DestinationAddresses</tt> is required if
--   <tt>AllowAllTrafficToEndpoint</tt> is <tt>FALSE</tt> or is not
--   specified.
[$sel:destinationAddresses:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: AllowCustomRoutingTraffic -> Maybe [Text]

-- | A list of specific Amazon EC2 instance ports (destination ports) that
--   you want to allow to receive traffic.
[$sel:destinationPorts:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: AllowCustomRoutingTraffic -> Maybe [Natural]

-- | Indicates whether all destination IP addresses and ports for a
--   specified VPC subnet endpoint can receive traffic from a custom
--   routing accelerator. The value is TRUE or FALSE.
--   
--   When set to TRUE, <i>all</i> destinations in the custom routing VPC
--   subnet can receive traffic. Note that you cannot specify destination
--   IP addresses and ports when the value is set to TRUE.
--   
--   When set to FALSE (or not specified), you <i>must</i> specify a list
--   of destination IP addresses that are allowed to receive traffic. A
--   list of ports is optional. If you don't specify a list of ports, the
--   ports that can accept traffic is the same as the ports configured for
--   the endpoint group.
--   
--   The default value is FALSE.
[$sel:allowAllTrafficToEndpoint:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: AllowCustomRoutingTraffic -> Maybe Bool

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: AllowCustomRoutingTraffic -> Text

-- | An ID for the endpoint. For custom routing accelerators, this is the
--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet ID.
[$sel:endpointId:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'] :: AllowCustomRoutingTraffic -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>AllowCustomRoutingTraffic</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationAddresses:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationAddresses</a> - A list of
--   specific Amazon EC2 instance IP addresses (destination addresses) in a
--   subnet that you want to allow to receive traffic. The IP addresses
--   must be a subset of the IP addresses that you specified for the
--   endpoint group.
--   
--   <tt>DestinationAddresses</tt> is required if
--   <tt>AllowAllTrafficToEndpoint</tt> is <tt>FALSE</tt> or is not
--   specified.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationPorts:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationPorts</a> - A list of specific
--   Amazon EC2 instance ports (destination ports) that you want to allow
--   to receive traffic.
--   
--   <a>$sel:allowAllTrafficToEndpoint:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_allowAllTrafficToEndpoint</a> - Indicates
--   whether all destination IP addresses and ports for a specified VPC
--   subnet endpoint can receive traffic from a custom routing accelerator.
--   The value is TRUE or FALSE.
--   
--   When set to TRUE, <i>all</i> destinations in the custom routing VPC
--   subnet can receive traffic. Note that you cannot specify destination
--   IP addresses and ports when the value is set to TRUE.
--   
--   When set to FALSE (or not specified), you <i>must</i> specify a list
--   of destination IP addresses that are allowed to receive traffic. A
--   list of ports is optional. If you don't specify a list of ports, the
--   ports that can accept traffic is the same as the ports configured for
--   the endpoint group.
--   
--   The default value is FALSE.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointId</a> - An ID for the endpoint.
--   For custom routing accelerators, this is the virtual private cloud
--   (VPC) subnet ID.
newAllowCustomRoutingTraffic :: Text -> Text -> AllowCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | A list of specific Amazon EC2 instance IP addresses (destination
--   addresses) in a subnet that you want to allow to receive traffic. The
--   IP addresses must be a subset of the IP addresses that you specified
--   for the endpoint group.
--   
--   <tt>DestinationAddresses</tt> is required if
--   <tt>AllowAllTrafficToEndpoint</tt> is <tt>FALSE</tt> or is not
--   specified.
allowCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationAddresses :: Lens' AllowCustomRoutingTraffic (Maybe [Text])

-- | A list of specific Amazon EC2 instance ports (destination ports) that
--   you want to allow to receive traffic.
allowCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationPorts :: Lens' AllowCustomRoutingTraffic (Maybe [Natural])

-- | Indicates whether all destination IP addresses and ports for a
--   specified VPC subnet endpoint can receive traffic from a custom
--   routing accelerator. The value is TRUE or FALSE.
--   
--   When set to TRUE, <i>all</i> destinations in the custom routing VPC
--   subnet can receive traffic. Note that you cannot specify destination
--   IP addresses and ports when the value is set to TRUE.
--   
--   When set to FALSE (or not specified), you <i>must</i> specify a list
--   of destination IP addresses that are allowed to receive traffic. A
--   list of ports is optional. If you don't specify a list of ports, the
--   ports that can accept traffic is the same as the ports configured for
--   the endpoint group.
--   
--   The default value is FALSE.
allowCustomRoutingTraffic_allowAllTrafficToEndpoint :: Lens' AllowCustomRoutingTraffic (Maybe Bool)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
allowCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' AllowCustomRoutingTraffic Text

-- | An ID for the endpoint. For custom routing accelerators, this is the
--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet ID.
allowCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointId :: Lens' AllowCustomRoutingTraffic Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAllowCustomRoutingTrafficResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.
data AllowCustomRoutingTrafficResponse
AllowCustomRoutingTrafficResponse' :: AllowCustomRoutingTrafficResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>AllowCustomRoutingTrafficResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newAllowCustomRoutingTrafficResponse :: AllowCustomRoutingTrafficResponse

-- | Advertises an IPv4 address range that is provisioned for use with your
--   AWS resources through bring your own IP addresses (BYOIP). It can take
--   a few minutes before traffic to the specified addresses starts routing
--   to AWS because of propagation delays.
--   
--   To stop advertising the BYOIP address range, use
--   <a>WithdrawByoipCidr</a>.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring Your Own IP Addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.AdvertiseByoipCidr

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAdvertiseByoipCidr</a> smart constructor.
data AdvertiseByoipCidr
AdvertiseByoipCidr' :: Text -> AdvertiseByoipCidr

-- | The address range, in CIDR notation. This must be the exact range that
--   you provisioned. You can't advertise only a portion of the provisioned
--   range.
[$sel:cidr:AdvertiseByoipCidr'] :: AdvertiseByoipCidr -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>AdvertiseByoipCidr</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--

--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidr:AdvertiseByoipCidr'</a>, <a>advertiseByoipCidr_cidr</a> -
--   The address range, in CIDR notation. This must be the exact range that
--   you provisioned. You can't advertise only a portion of the provisioned
--   range.
newAdvertiseByoipCidr :: Text -> AdvertiseByoipCidr

-- | The address range, in CIDR notation. This must be the exact range that
--   you provisioned. You can't advertise only a portion of the provisioned
--   range.

-- | Associate a virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet endpoint with your
--   custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   The listener port range must be large enough to support the number of
--   IP addresses that can be specified in your subnet. The number of ports
--   required is: subnet size times the number of ports per destination EC2
--   instances. For example, a subnet defined as /24 requires a listener
--   port range of at least 255 ports.
--   
--   Note: You must have enough remaining listener ports available to map
--   to the subnet ports, or the call will fail with a
--   LimitExceededException.
--   
--   By default, all destinations in a subnet in a custom routing
--   accelerator cannot receive traffic. To enable all destinations to
--   receive traffic, or to specify individual port mappings that can
--   receive traffic, see the <a>AllowCustomRoutingTraffic</a> operation.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.AddCustomRoutingEndpoints

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAddCustomRoutingEndpoints</a> smart constructor.
data AddCustomRoutingEndpoints
AddCustomRoutingEndpoints' :: NonEmpty CustomRoutingEndpointConfiguration -> Text -> AddCustomRoutingEndpoints

-- | The list of endpoint objects to add to a custom routing accelerator.
[$sel:endpointConfigurations:AddCustomRoutingEndpoints'] :: AddCustomRoutingEndpoints -> NonEmpty CustomRoutingEndpointConfiguration

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group for the custom
--   routing endpoint.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:AddCustomRoutingEndpoints'] :: AddCustomRoutingEndpoints -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>AddCustomRoutingEndpoints</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointConfigurations:AddCustomRoutingEndpoints'</a>,
--   <a>addCustomRoutingEndpoints_endpointConfigurations</a> - The list of
--   endpoint objects to add to a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:AddCustomRoutingEndpoints'</a>,
--   <a>addCustomRoutingEndpoints_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group for the custom routing
--   endpoint.
newAddCustomRoutingEndpoints :: NonEmpty CustomRoutingEndpointConfiguration -> Text -> AddCustomRoutingEndpoints

-- | The list of endpoint objects to add to a custom routing accelerator.
addCustomRoutingEndpoints_endpointConfigurations :: Lens' AddCustomRoutingEndpoints (NonEmpty CustomRoutingEndpointConfiguration)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group for the custom
--   routing endpoint.
addCustomRoutingEndpoints_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' AddCustomRoutingEndpoints Text

--   constructor.

-- | Remove tags from a Global Accelerator resource. When you specify a tag
--   key, the action removes both that key and its associated value. The
--   operation succeeds even if you attempt to remove tags from an
--   accelerator that was already removed.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Tagging in AWS Global Accelerator</a> in
--   the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.

-- | Update an accelerator.
--   
--   Global Accelerator is a global service that supports endpoints in
--   multiple AWS Regions but you must specify the US West (Oregon) Region
--   to create or update accelerators.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateAccelerator

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateAccelerator</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateAccelerator
UpdateAccelerator' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateAccelerator

-- | Indicates whether an accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
[$sel:enabled:UpdateAccelerator'] :: UpdateAccelerator -> Maybe Bool

-- | The IP address type, which must be IPv4.
[$sel:ipAddressType:UpdateAccelerator'] :: UpdateAccelerator -> Maybe IpAddressType

-- | The name of the accelerator. The name can have a maximum of 32
--   characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-),
--   and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
[$sel:name:UpdateAccelerator'] :: UpdateAccelerator -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator to update.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:UpdateAccelerator'] :: UpdateAccelerator -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateAccelerator</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:enabled:UpdateAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>updateAccelerator_enabled</a> - Indicates whether an accelerator is
--   enabled. The value is true or false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:UpdateAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>updateAccelerator_ipAddressType</a> - The IP address type, which
--   must be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:UpdateAccelerator'</a>, <a>updateAccelerator_name</a> -
--   The name of the accelerator. The name can have a maximum of 32
--   characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-),
--   and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:UpdateAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>updateAccelerator_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the accelerator to update.
newUpdateAccelerator :: Text -> UpdateAccelerator

-- | Indicates whether an accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
updateAccelerator_enabled :: Lens' UpdateAccelerator (Maybe Bool)

-- | The IP address type, which must be IPv4.
updateAccelerator_ipAddressType :: Lens' UpdateAccelerator (Maybe IpAddressType)

-- | The name of the accelerator. The name can have a maximum of 32
--   characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-),
--   and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
updateAccelerator_name :: Lens' UpdateAccelerator (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator to update.
updateAccelerator_acceleratorArn :: Lens' UpdateAccelerator Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateAcceleratorResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateAcceleratorResponse
UpdateAcceleratorResponse' :: Maybe Accelerator -> Int -> UpdateAcceleratorResponse

[$sel:accelerator:UpdateAcceleratorResponse'] :: UpdateAcceleratorResponse -> Maybe Accelerator

--   <a>updateAcceleratorResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http

-- | Update the attributes for an accelerator.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateAcceleratorAttributes

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateAcceleratorAttributes</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateAcceleratorAttributes
UpdateAcceleratorAttributes' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateAcceleratorAttributes

-- | Update the prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the
--   flow logs. Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is
--   <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   s3-bucket_name//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
[$sel:flowLogsS3Prefix:UpdateAcceleratorAttributes'] :: UpdateAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | Update whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false. If
--   the value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:flowLogsEnabled:UpdateAcceleratorAttributes'] :: UpdateAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Bool

-- | The name of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is
--   required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must
--   exist and have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator
--   permission to write to the bucket.
[$sel:flowLogsS3Bucket:UpdateAcceleratorAttributes'] :: UpdateAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator that you want to
--   update.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:UpdateAcceleratorAttributes'] :: UpdateAcceleratorAttributes -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateAcceleratorAttributes</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsS3Prefix:UpdateAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>updateAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Prefix</a> - Update the
--   prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs.
--   Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   s3-bucket_name//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsEnabled:UpdateAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>updateAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled</a> - Update whether
--   flow logs are enabled. The default value is false. If the value is
--   true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be
--   specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsS3Bucket:UpdateAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>updateAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Bucket</a> - The name of the
--   Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is required if
--   <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must exist and
--   have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator permission to
--   write to the bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:UpdateAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>updateAcceleratorAttributes_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator that you want to update.
newUpdateAcceleratorAttributes :: Text -> UpdateAcceleratorAttributes

-- | Update the prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the
--   flow logs. Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is
--   <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   s3-bucket_name//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
updateAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Prefix :: Lens' UpdateAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Text)

-- | Update whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false. If
--   the value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
updateAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled :: Lens' UpdateAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Bool)

-- | The name of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is
--   required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must
--   exist and have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator
--   permission to write to the bucket.
updateAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Bucket :: Lens' UpdateAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator that you want to
--   update.
updateAcceleratorAttributes_acceleratorArn :: Lens' UpdateAcceleratorAttributes Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateAcceleratorAttributesResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.

UpdateAcceleratorAttributesResponse' :: Maybe AcceleratorAttributes -> Int -> UpdateAcceleratorAttributesResponse

-- | Update a custom routing accelerator.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator</a> smart
--   constructor.
data UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator
UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | Indicates whether an accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
[$sel:enabled:UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe Bool

-- | The value for the address type must be IPv4.
[$sel:ipAddressType:UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe IpAddressType

-- | The name of the accelerator. The name can have a maximum of 32
--   characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-),
--   and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
[$sel:name:UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator to update.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--

--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAccelerator_enabled</a> - Indicates whether an
--   accelerator is enabled. The value is true or false. The default value
--   is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAccelerator_ipAddressType</a> - The value for
--   the address type must be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAccelerator_name</a> - The name of the
--   accelerator. The name can have a maximum of 32 characters, must
--   contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-), and must not
--   begin or end with a hyphen.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:UpdateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAccelerator_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the accelerator to update.

-- | Indicates whether an accelerator is enabled. The value is true or

--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.

-- | Update the attributes for a custom routing accelerator.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes</a> smart
--   constructor.
data UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> Text -> UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes

-- | Update the prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the
--   flow logs. Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is
--   <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   DOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
[$sel:flowLogsS3Prefix:UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | Update whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false. If
--   the value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:flowLogsEnabled:UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Bool

-- | The name of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is
--   required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must
--   exist and have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator
--   permission to write to the bucket.
[$sel:flowLogsS3Bucket:UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes -> Maybe Text

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator to
--   update attributes for.
[$sel:acceleratorArn:UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes -> Text

--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled</a> -

-- | Update a listener for a custom routing accelerator.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateCustomRoutingListener

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateCustomRoutingListener</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateCustomRoutingListener
UpdateCustomRoutingListener' :: Text -> NonEmpty PortRange -> UpdateCustomRoutingListener

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener to update.
[$sel:listenerArn:UpdateCustomRoutingListener'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingListener -> Text

-- | The updated port range to support for connections from clients to your
--   accelerator. If you remove ports that are currently being used by a
--   subnet endpoint, the call fails.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
[$sel:portRanges:UpdateCustomRoutingListener'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingListener -> NonEmpty PortRange

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateCustomRoutingListener</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerArn:UpdateCustomRoutingListener'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingListener_listenerArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the listener to update.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portRanges:UpdateCustomRoutingListener'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingListener_portRanges</a> - The updated port range
--   to support for connections from clients to your accelerator. If you
--   remove ports that are currently being used by a subnet endpoint, the
--   call fails.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
newUpdateCustomRoutingListener :: Text -> NonEmpty PortRange -> UpdateCustomRoutingListener

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener to update.
updateCustomRoutingListener_listenerArn :: Lens' UpdateCustomRoutingListener Text

-- | The updated port range to support for connections from clients to your
--   accelerator. If you remove ports that are currently being used by a
--   subnet endpoint, the call fails.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
updateCustomRoutingListener_portRanges :: Lens' UpdateCustomRoutingListener (NonEmpty PortRange)

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.
data UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse
UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse' :: Maybe CustomRoutingListener -> Int -> UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse

-- | Information for the updated listener for a custom routing accelerator.
[$sel:listener:UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse -> Maybe CustomRoutingListener

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse'] :: UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   the updated listener for a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingListenerResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's
--   http status code.
newUpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse :: Int -> UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse

-- | Information for the updated listener for a custom routing accelerator.
updateCustomRoutingListenerResponse_listener :: Lens' UpdateCustomRoutingListenerResponse (Maybe CustomRoutingListener)

-- | Update an endpoint group. A resource must be valid and active when you
--   add it as an endpoint.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateEndpointGroup

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateEndpointGroup</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateEndpointGroup
UpdateEndpointGroup' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol -> Maybe Double -> Maybe [EndpointConfiguration] -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe [PortOverride] -> Text -> UpdateEndpointGroup

-- | The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a
--   healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to
--   healthy. The default value is 3.
[$sel:thresholdCount:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | If the protocol is HTTP/S, then this specifies the path that is the
--   destination for health check targets. The default value is slash (/).
[$sel:healthCheckPath:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Text

-- | The time—10 seconds or 30 seconds—between each health check for an
--   endpoint. The default value is 30.
[$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | The protocol that AWS Global Accelerator uses to check the health of
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default value is
--   TCP.
[$sel:healthCheckProtocol:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol

-- | The percentage of traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic
--   is distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
[$sel:trafficDialPercentage:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Double

-- | The list of endpoint objects. A resource must be valid and active when
--   you add it as an endpoint.
[$sel:endpointConfigurations:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Maybe [EndpointConfiguration]

-- | The port that AWS Global Accelerator uses to check the health of
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default port is
--   the listener port that this endpoint group is associated with. If the
--   listener port is a list of ports, Global Accelerator uses the first
--   port in the list.
[$sel:healthCheckPort:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Maybe Natural

-- | Override specific listener ports used to route traffic to endpoints
--   that are part of this endpoint group. For example, you can create a
--   port override in which the listener receives user traffic on ports 80
--   and 443, but your accelerator routes that traffic to ports 1080 and
--   1443, respectively, on the endpoints.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Port overrides</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
[$sel:portOverrides:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Maybe [PortOverride]

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
[$sel:endpointGroupArn:UpdateEndpointGroup'] :: UpdateEndpointGroup -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateEndpointGroup</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:thresholdCount:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_thresholdCount</a> - The number of consecutive
--   health checks required to set the state of a healthy endpoint to
--   unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to healthy. The default
--   value is 3.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPath:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckPath</a> - If the protocol is
--   HTTP/S, then this specifies the path that is the destination for
--   health check targets. The default value is slash (/).
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds</a> - The time—10
--   seconds or 30 seconds—between each health check for an endpoint. The
--   default value is 30.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckProtocol:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol</a> - The protocol that AWS
--   Global Accelerator uses to check the health of endpoints that are part
--   of this endpoint group. The default value is TCP.
--   
--   <a>$sel:trafficDialPercentage:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage</a> - The percentage of
--   traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic is distributed to
--   other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointConfigurations:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_endpointConfigurations</a> - The list of
--   endpoint objects. A resource must be valid and active when you add it
--   as an endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPort:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckPort</a> - The port that AWS Global
--   Accelerator uses to check the health of endpoints that are part of
--   this endpoint group. The default port is the listener port that this
--   endpoint group is associated with. If the listener port is a list of
--   ports, Global Accelerator uses the first port in the list.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portOverrides:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_portOverrides</a> - Override specific listener
--   ports used to route traffic to endpoints that are part of this
--   endpoint group. For example, you can create a port override in which
--   the listener receives user traffic on ports 80 and 443, but your
--   accelerator routes that traffic to ports 1080 and 1443, respectively,
--   on the endpoints.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Port overrides</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the endpoint group.
newUpdateEndpointGroup :: Text -> UpdateEndpointGroup

-- | The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a
--   healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to
--   healthy. The default value is 3.
updateEndpointGroup_thresholdCount :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | If the protocol is HTTP/S, then this specifies the path that is the
--   destination for health check targets. The default value is slash (/).
updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckPath :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The time—10 seconds or 30 seconds—between each health check for an
--   endpoint. The default value is 30.
updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | The protocol that AWS Global Accelerator uses to check the health of
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default value is
--   TCP.
updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup (Maybe HealthCheckProtocol)

-- | The percentage of traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic
--   is distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
updateEndpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup (Maybe Double)

-- | The list of endpoint objects. A resource must be valid and active when
--   you add it as an endpoint.
updateEndpointGroup_endpointConfigurations :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup (Maybe [EndpointConfiguration])

-- | The port that AWS Global Accelerator uses to check the health of
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default port is
--   the listener port that this endpoint group is associated with. If the
--   listener port is a list of ports, Global Accelerator uses the first
--   port in the list.
updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckPort :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | Override specific listener ports used to route traffic to endpoints
--   that are part of this endpoint group. For example, you can create a
--   port override in which the listener receives user traffic on ports 80
--   and 443, but your accelerator routes that traffic to ports 1080 and
--   1443, respectively, on the endpoints.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Port overrides</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
updateEndpointGroup_portOverrides :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup (Maybe [PortOverride])

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
updateEndpointGroup_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' UpdateEndpointGroup Text

-- | Update a listener.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateListener

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateListener</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateListener
UpdateListener' :: Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange) -> Maybe Protocol -> Maybe ClientAffinity -> Text -> UpdateListener

-- | The updated list of port ranges for the connections from clients to
--   the accelerator.
[$sel:portRanges:UpdateListener'] :: UpdateListener -> Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange)

-- | The updated protocol for the connections from clients to the
--   accelerator.
[$sel:protocol:UpdateListener'] :: UpdateListener -> Maybe Protocol

-- | Client affinity lets you direct all requests from a user to the same
--   endpoint, if you have stateful applications, regardless of the port
--   and protocol of the client request. Client affinity gives you control
--   over whether to always route each client to the same specific
--   endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
[$sel:clientAffinity:UpdateListener'] :: UpdateListener -> Maybe ClientAffinity

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener to update.
[$sel:listenerArn:UpdateListener'] :: UpdateListener -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateListener</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:portRanges:UpdateListener'</a>,
--   <a>updateListener_portRanges</a> - The updated list of port ranges for
--   the connections from clients to the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:UpdateListener'</a>, <a>updateListener_protocol</a> -
--   The updated protocol for the connections from clients to the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientAffinity:UpdateListener'</a>,
--   <a>updateListener_clientAffinity</a> - Client affinity lets you direct
--   all requests from a user to the same endpoint, if you have stateful
--   applications, regardless of the port and protocol of the client
--   request. Client affinity gives you control over whether to always
--   route each client to the same specific endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerArn:UpdateListener'</a>,
--   <a>updateListener_listenerArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the listener to update.
newUpdateListener :: Text -> UpdateListener

-- | The updated list of port ranges for the connections from clients to
--   the accelerator.
updateListener_portRanges :: Lens' UpdateListener (Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange))

-- | The updated protocol for the connections from clients to the
--   accelerator.
updateListener_protocol :: Lens' UpdateListener (Maybe Protocol)

-- | Client affinity lets you direct all requests from a user to the same
--   endpoint, if you have stateful applications, regardless of the port
--   and protocol of the client request. Client affinity gives you control
--   over whether to always route each client to the same specific
--   endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
updateListener_clientAffinity :: Lens' UpdateListener (Maybe ClientAffinity)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener to update.
updateListener_listenerArn :: Lens' UpdateListener Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateListenerResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateListenerResponse
UpdateListenerResponse' :: Maybe Listener -> Int -> UpdateListenerResponse

-- | Information for the updated listener.
[$sel:listener:UpdateListenerResponse'] :: UpdateListenerResponse -> Maybe Listener

[$sel:httpStatus:UpdateListenerResponse'] :: UpdateListenerResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateListenerResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.

--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--

--   <a>updateListenerResponse_listener</a> - Information for the updated
--   listener.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:UpdateListenerResponse'</a>,
--   <a>updateListenerResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http status
--   code.
newUpdateListenerResponse :: Int -> UpdateListenerResponse

instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateListener.UpdateListenerResponse

instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateListener.UpdateListener
instance Amazonka.Data.Headers.ToHeaders Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateListener.UpdateListener

instance Amazonka.Data.Path.ToPath Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateListener.UpdateListener
instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.UpdateListener.UpdateListener


-- | Stops advertising an address range that is provisioned as an address
--   pool. You can perform this operation at most once every 10 seconds,
--   even if you specify different address ranges each time.
--   
--   It can take a few minutes before traffic to the specified addresses
--   stops routing to AWS because of propagation delays.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring Your Own IP Addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.WithdrawByoipCidr

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newWithdrawByoipCidr</a> smart constructor.
data WithdrawByoipCidr
WithdrawByoipCidr' :: Text -> WithdrawByoipCidr

-- | The address range, in CIDR notation.
[$sel:cidr:WithdrawByoipCidr'] :: WithdrawByoipCidr -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>WithdrawByoipCidr</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidr:WithdrawByoipCidr'</a>, <a>withdrawByoipCidr_cidr</a> -
--   The address range, in CIDR notation.
newWithdrawByoipCidr :: Text -> WithdrawByoipCidr

-- | The address range, in CIDR notation.
withdrawByoipCidr_cidr :: Lens' WithdrawByoipCidr Text

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newWithdrawByoipCidrResponse</a> smart constructor.
data WithdrawByoipCidrResponse
WithdrawByoipCidrResponse' :: Maybe ByoipCidr -> Int -> WithdrawByoipCidrResponse

-- | Information about the address pool.
[$sel:byoipCidr:WithdrawByoipCidrResponse'] :: WithdrawByoipCidrResponse -> Maybe ByoipCidr

-- | The response's http status code.
[$sel:httpStatus:WithdrawByoipCidrResponse'] :: WithdrawByoipCidrResponse -> Int

-- | Create a value of <a>WithdrawByoipCidrResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:byoipCidr:WithdrawByoipCidrResponse'</a>,
--   <a>withdrawByoipCidrResponse_byoipCidr</a> - Information about the
--   address pool.
--   
--   <a>$sel:httpStatus:WithdrawByoipCidrResponse'</a>,
--   <a>withdrawByoipCidrResponse_httpStatus</a> - The response's http
--   status code.
newWithdrawByoipCidrResponse :: Int -> WithdrawByoipCidrResponse

-- | Information about the address pool.
withdrawByoipCidrResponse_byoipCidr :: Lens' WithdrawByoipCidrResponse (Maybe ByoipCidr)

-- | The response's http status code.
withdrawByoipCidrResponse_httpStatus :: Lens' WithdrawByoipCidrResponse Int

instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.WithdrawByoipCidr.WithdrawByoipCidr
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.WithdrawByoipCidr.WithdrawByoipCidr
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.WithdrawByoipCidr.WithdrawByoipCidr
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.WithdrawByoipCidr.WithdrawByoipCidrResponse
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.WithdrawByoipCidr.WithdrawByoipCidrResponse

instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.WithdrawByoipCidr.WithdrawByoipCidrResponse
