--   accelerator.
customRoutingAccelerator_ipSets :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe [IpSet])

-- | The Domain Name System (DNS) name that Global Accelerator creates that
--   points to your accelerator's static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
customRoutingAccelerator_dnsName :: Lens' CustomRoutingAccelerator (Maybe Text)

-- | The prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs.
--   Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   DOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Prefix :: Lens' CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false.
--   If the value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled :: Lens' CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Bool)

-- | The name of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is
--   required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must
--   exist and have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator
--   permission to write to the bucket.
customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Bucket :: Lens' CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes (Maybe Text)

-- | The first port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint
--   group that is associated with a custom routing accelerator.
customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_fromPort :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration Natural

-- | The last port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint group
--   that is associated with a custom routing accelerator.
customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_toPort :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration Natural

-- | The protocol for the endpoint group that is associated with a custom
--   routing accelerator. The protocol can be either TCP or UDP.
customRoutingDestinationConfiguration_protocols :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration (NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol)

-- | The first port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint
--   group that is associated with a custom routing accelerator.
customRoutingDestinationDescription_fromPort :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationDescription (Maybe Natural)

-- | The protocol for the endpoint group that is associated with a custom
--   routing accelerator. The protocol can be either TCP or UDP.
customRoutingDestinationDescription_protocols :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationDescription (Maybe [Protocol])

-- | The last port, inclusive, in the range of ports for the endpoint group
--   that is associated with a custom routing accelerator.
customRoutingDestinationDescription_toPort :: Lens' CustomRoutingDestinationDescription (Maybe Natural)

-- | An ID for the endpoint. For custom routing accelerators, this is the
--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet ID.
customRoutingEndpointConfiguration_endpointId :: Lens' CustomRoutingEndpointConfiguration (Maybe Text)

-- | An ID for the endpoint. For custom routing accelerators, this is the
--   virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet ID.
customRoutingEndpointDescription_endpointId :: Lens' CustomRoutingEndpointDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
customRoutingEndpointGroup_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' CustomRoutingEndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The AWS Region where the endpoint group is located.
customRoutingEndpointGroup_endpointGroupRegion :: Lens' CustomRoutingEndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | For a custom routing accelerator, describes the endpoints (virtual
--   private cloud subnets) in an endpoint group to accept client traffic
--   on.
customRoutingEndpointGroup_endpointDescriptions :: Lens' CustomRoutingEndpointGroup (Maybe [CustomRoutingEndpointDescription])

-- | For a custom routing accelerator, describes the port range and
--   protocol for all endpoints (virtual private cloud subnets) in an
--   endpoint group to accept client traffic on.
customRoutingEndpointGroup_destinationDescriptions :: Lens' CustomRoutingEndpointGroup (Maybe [CustomRoutingDestinationDescription])

-- | The port range to support for connections from clients to your
--   accelerator.
--   
--   Separately, you set port ranges for endpoints. For more information,
--   see <a>About endpoints for custom routing accelerators</a>.
customRoutingListener_portRanges :: Lens' CustomRoutingListener (Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange))

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
customRoutingListener_listenerArn :: Lens' CustomRoutingListener (Maybe Text)

-- | The endpoint IP address/port combination for traffic received on the
--   accelerator socket address.
destinationPortMapping_destinationSocketAddress :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe SocketAddress)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator that
--   you have port mappings for.
destinationPortMapping_acceleratorArn :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
destinationPortMapping_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | The AWS Region for the endpoint group.
destinationPortMapping_endpointGroupRegion :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP address type, which must be IPv4.
destinationPortMapping_ipAddressType :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe IpAddressType)

-- | The IP address/port combinations (sockets) that map to a given
--   destination socket address.
destinationPortMapping_acceleratorSocketAddresses :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe [SocketAddress])

-- | The ID for the virtual private cloud (VPC) subnet.
destinationPortMapping_endpointId :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether or not a port mapping destination can receive
--   traffic. The value is either ALLOW, if traffic is allowed to the
--   destination, or DENY, if traffic is not allowed to the destination.
destinationPortMapping_destinationTrafficState :: Lens' DestinationPortMapping (Maybe CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState)

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointConfiguration_weight :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Natural)

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Preserve Client IP Addresses in AWS
--   Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer
--   Guide</i>.
endpointConfiguration_clientIPPreservationEnabled :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Bool)

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID. A resource must be valid and active when you add
--   it as an endpoint.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
endpointConfiguration_endpointId :: Lens' EndpointConfiguration (Maybe Text)

-- | Returns a null result.
endpointDescription_healthReason :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The weight associated with the endpoint. When you add weights to
--   endpoints, you configure AWS Global Accelerator to route traffic based
--   on proportions that you specify. For example, you might specify
--   endpoint weights of 4, 5, 5, and 6 (sum=20). The result is that 4/20
--   of your traffic, on average, is routed to the first endpoint, 5/20 is
--   routed both to the second and third endpoints, and 6/20 is routed to
--   the last endpoint. For more information, see <a>Endpoint Weights</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointDescription_weight :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Natural)

-- | Indicates whether client IP address preservation is enabled for an
--   Application Load Balancer endpoint. The value is true or false. The
--   default value is true for new accelerators.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the client's IP address is preserved in
--   the <tt>X-Forwarded-For</tt> request header as traffic travels to
--   applications on the Application Load Balancer endpoint fronted by the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Viewing Client IP Addresses in AWS Global
--   Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
endpointDescription_clientIPPreservationEnabled :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Bool)

-- | The health status of the endpoint.
endpointDescription_healthState :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe HealthState)

-- | An ID for the endpoint. If the endpoint is a Network Load Balancer or
--   Application Load Balancer, this is the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the resource. If the endpoint is an Elastic IP address, this is the
--   Elastic IP address allocation ID. For Amazon EC2 instances, this is
--   the EC2 instance ID.
--   
--   An Application Load Balancer can be either internal or
--   internet-facing.
endpointDescription_endpointId :: Lens' EndpointDescription (Maybe Text)

-- | The number of consecutive health checks required to set the state of a
--   healthy endpoint to unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to
--   healthy. The default value is 3.
endpointGroup_thresholdCount :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | If the protocol is HTTP/S, then this value provides the ping path that
--   Global Accelerator uses for the destination on the endpoints for
--   health checks. The default is slash (/).
endpointGroup_healthCheckPath :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The time—10 seconds or 30 seconds—between health checks for each
--   endpoint. The default value is 30.
endpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
endpointGroup_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group. The default value is
--   TCP.
endpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe HealthCheckProtocol)

-- | The AWS Region where the endpoint group is located.
endpointGroup_endpointGroupRegion :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Text)

-- | The percentage of traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic
--   is distributed to other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
endpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Double)

-- | The port that Global Accelerator uses to perform health checks on
--   endpoints that are part of this endpoint group.
--   
--   The default port is the port for the listener that this endpoint group
--   is associated with. If the listener port is a list, Global Accelerator
--   uses the first specified port in the list of ports.
endpointGroup_healthCheckPort :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe Natural)

-- | Allows you to override the destination ports used to route traffic to
--   an endpoint. Using a port override lets you to map a list of external
--   destination ports (that your users send traffic to) to a list of
--   internal destination ports that you want an application endpoint to
--   receive traffic on.
endpointGroup_portOverrides :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe [PortOverride])

-- | The list of endpoint objects.
endpointGroup_endpointDescriptions :: Lens' EndpointGroup (Maybe [EndpointDescription])

-- | The types of IP addresses included in this IP set.
ipSet_ipFamily :: Lens' IpSet (Maybe Text)

-- | The array of IP addresses in the IP address set. An IP address set can
--   have a maximum of two IP addresses.
ipSet_ipAddresses :: Lens' IpSet (Maybe [Text])

-- | The list of port ranges for the connections from clients to the
--   accelerator.
listener_portRanges :: Lens' Listener (Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange))

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the listener.
listener_listenerArn :: Lens' Listener (Maybe Text)

-- | The protocol for the connections from clients to the accelerator.
listener_protocol :: Lens' Listener (Maybe Protocol)

-- | Client affinity lets you direct all requests from a user to the same
--   endpoint, if you have stateful applications, regardless of the port
--   and protocol of the client request. Client affinity gives you control
--   over whether to always route each client to the same specific
--   endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
listener_clientAffinity :: Lens' Listener (Maybe ClientAffinity)

-- | The EC2 instance IP address and port number in the virtual private
--   cloud (VPC) subnet.
portMapping_destinationSocketAddress :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe SocketAddress)

-- | The protocols supported by the endpoint group.
portMapping_protocols :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe (NonEmpty CustomRoutingProtocol))

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
portMapping_endpointGroupArn :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP address of the VPC subnet (the subnet ID).
portMapping_endpointId :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe Text)

-- | Indicates whether or not a port mapping destination can receive
--   traffic. The value is either ALLOW, if traffic is allowed to the
--   destination, or DENY, if traffic is not allowed to the destination.
portMapping_destinationTrafficState :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState)

-- | The accelerator port.
portMapping_acceleratorPort :: Lens' PortMapping (Maybe Natural)

-- | The endpoint port that you want a listener port to be mapped to. This
--   is the port on the endpoint, such as the Application Load Balancer or
--   Amazon EC2 instance.
portOverride_endpointPort :: Lens' PortOverride (Maybe Natural)

-- | The listener port that you want to map to a specific endpoint port.
--   This is the port that user traffic arrives to the Global Accelerator
--   on.
portOverride_listenerPort :: Lens' PortOverride (Maybe Natural)

-- | The first port in the range of ports, inclusive.
portRange_fromPort :: Lens' PortRange (Maybe Natural)

-- | The last port in the range of ports, inclusive.
portRange_toPort :: Lens' PortRange (Maybe Natural)

-- | The IP address for the socket address.
socketAddress_ipAddress :: Lens' SocketAddress (Maybe Text)

-- | The port for the socket address.
socketAddress_port :: Lens' SocketAddress (Maybe Natural)

-- | A string that contains a <tt>Tag</tt> key.
tag_key :: Lens' Tag Text

-- | A string that contains a <tt>Tag</tt> value.
tag_value :: Lens' Tag Text


module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator.Waiters


-- | Derived from API version <tt>2018-08-08</tt> of the AWS service
--   descriptions, licensed under Apache 2.0.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator
--   
--   This is the <i>AWS Global Accelerator API Reference</i>. This guide is
--   for developers who need detailed information about AWS Global
--   Accelerator API actions, data types, and errors. For more information
--   about Global Accelerator features, see the <a>AWS Global Accelerator
--   Developer Guide</a>.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator is a service in which you create
--   <i>accelerators</i> to improve the performance of your applications
--   for local and global users. Depending on the type of accelerator you
--   choose, you can gain additional benefits.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>By using a standard accelerator, you can improve availability of
--   your internet applications that are used by a global audience. With a
--   standard accelerator, Global Accelerator directs traffic to optimal
--   endpoints over the AWS global network.</li>
--   <li>For other scenarios, you might choose a custom routing
--   accelerator. With a custom routing accelerator, you can use
--   application logic to directly map one or more users to a specific
--   endpoint among many endpoints.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   Global Accelerator is a global service that supports endpoints in
--   multiple AWS Regions but you must specify the US West (Oregon) Region
--   to create or update accelerators.
--   
--   By default, Global Accelerator provides you with two static IP
--   addresses that you associate with your accelerator. With a standard
--   accelerator, instead of using the IP addresses that Global Accelerator
--   provides, you can configure these entry points to be IPv4 addresses
--   from your own IP address ranges that you bring to Global Accelerator.
--   The static IP addresses are anycast from the AWS edge network. For a
--   standard accelerator, they distribute incoming application traffic
--   across multiple endpoint resources in multiple AWS Regions, which
--   increases the availability of your applications. Endpoints for
--   standard accelerators can be Network Load Balancers, Application Load
--   Balancers, Amazon EC2 instances, or Elastic IP addresses that are
--   located in one AWS Region or multiple Regions. For custom routing
--   accelerators, you map traffic that arrives to the static IP addresses
--   to specific Amazon EC2 servers in endpoints that are virtual private
--   cloud (VPC) subnets.
--   
--   The static IP addresses remain assigned to your accelerator for as
--   long as it exists, even if you disable the accelerator and it no
--   longer accepts or routes traffic. However, when you <i>delete</i> an
--   accelerator, you lose the static IP addresses that are assigned to it,
--   so you can no longer route traffic by using them. You can use IAM
--   policies like tag-based permissions with Global Accelerator to limit
--   the users who have permissions to delete an accelerator. For more
--   information, see <a>Tag-based policies</a>.
--   
--   For standard accelerators, Global Accelerator uses the AWS global
--   network to route traffic to the optimal regional endpoint based on
--   health, client location, and policies that you configure. The service
--   reacts instantly to changes in health or configuration to ensure that
--   internet traffic from clients is always directed to healthy endpoints.
--   
--   For a list of the AWS Regions where Global Accelerator and other
--   services are currently supported, see the <a>AWS Region Table</a>.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator includes the following components:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><i>Static IP addresses</i> Global Accelerator provides you with a
--   set of two static IP addresses that are anycast from the AWS edge
--   network. If you bring your own IP address range to AWS (BYOIP) to use
--   with a standard accelerator, you can instead assign IP addresses from
--   your own pool to use with your accelerator. For more information, see
--   <a>Bring your own IP addresses (BYOIP) in AWS Global
--   Accelerator</a>.The IP addresses serve as single fixed entry points
--   for your clients. If you already have Elastic Load Balancing load
--   balancers, Amazon EC2 instances, or Elastic IP address resources set
--   up for your applications, you can easily add those to a standard
--   accelerator in Global Accelerator. This allows Global Accelerator to
--   use static IP addresses to access the resources.The static IP
--   addresses remain assigned to your accelerator for as long as it
--   exists, even if you disable the accelerator and it no longer accepts
--   or routes traffic. However, when you <i>delete</i> an accelerator, you
--   lose the static IP addresses that are assigned to it, so you can no
--   longer route traffic by using them. You can use IAM policies like
--   tag-based permissions with Global Accelerator to delete an
--   accelerator. For more information, see <a>Tag-based policies</a>.</li>
--   <li><i>Accelerator</i> An accelerator directs traffic to endpoints
--   over the AWS global network to improve the performance of your
--   internet applications. Each accelerator includes one or more
--   listeners.There are two types of accelerators:<ul><li>A
--   <i>standard</i> accelerator directs traffic to the optimal AWS
--   endpoint based on several factors, including the user’s location, the
--   health of the endpoint, and the endpoint weights that you configure.
--   This improves the availability and performance of your applications.
--   Endpoints can be Network Load Balancers, Application Load Balancers,
--   Amazon EC2 instances, or Elastic IP addresses.</li><li>A <i>custom
--   routing</i> accelerator directs traffic to one of possibly thousands
--   of Amazon EC2 instances running in a single or multiple virtual
--   private clouds (VPCs). With custom routing, listener ports are mapped
--   to statically associate port ranges with VPC subnets, which allows
--   Global Accelerator to determine an EC2 instance IP address at the time
--   of connection. By default, all port mapping destinations in a VPC
--   subnet can't receive traffic. You can choose to configure all
--   destinations in the subnet to receive traffic, or to specify
--   individual port mappings that can receive traffic.</li></ul>For more
--   information, see <a>Types of accelerators</a>.</li>
--   <li><i>DNS name</i> Global Accelerator assigns each accelerator a
--   default Domain Name System (DNS) name, similar to
--   <tt>a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com</tt>, that points to
--   the static IP addresses that Global Accelerator assigns to you or that
--   you choose from your own IP address range. Depending on the use case,
--   you can use your accelerator's static IP addresses or DNS name to
--   route traffic to your accelerator, or set up DNS records to route
--   traffic using your own custom domain name.</li>
--   <li><i>Network zone</i> A network zone services the static IP
--   addresses for your accelerator from a unique IP subnet. Similar to an
--   AWS Availability Zone, a network zone is an isolated unit with its own
--   set of physical infrastructure. When you configure an accelerator, by
--   default, Global Accelerator allocates two IPv4 addresses for it. If
--   one IP address from a network zone becomes unavailable due to IP
--   address blocking by certain client networks, or network disruptions,
--   then client applications can retry on the healthy static IP address
--   from the other isolated network zone.</li>
--   <li><i>Listener</i> A listener processes inbound connections from
--   clients to Global Accelerator, based on the port (or port range) and
--   protocol (or protocols) that you configure. A listener can be
--   configured for TCP, UDP, or both TCP and UDP protocols. Each listener
--   has one or more endpoint groups associated with it, and traffic is
--   forwarded to endpoints in one of the groups. You associate endpoint
--   groups with listeners by specifying the Regions that you want to
--   distribute traffic to. With a standard accelerator, traffic is
--   distributed to optimal endpoints within the endpoint groups associated
--   with a listener.</li>
--   <li><i>Endpoint group</i> Each endpoint group is associated with a
--   specific AWS Region. Endpoint groups include one or more endpoints in
--   the Region. With a standard accelerator, you can increase or reduce
--   the percentage of traffic that would be otherwise directed to an
--   endpoint group by adjusting a setting called a <i>traffic dial</i>.
--   The traffic dial lets you easily do performance testing or blue/green
--   deployment testing, for example, for new releases across different AWS
--   Regions.</li>
--   <li><i>Endpoint</i> An endpoint is a resource that Global Accelerator
--   directs traffic to.Endpoints for standard accelerators can be Network
--   Load Balancers, Application Load Balancers, Amazon EC2 instances, or
--   Elastic IP addresses. An Application Load Balancer endpoint can be
--   internet-facing or internal. Traffic for standard accelerators is
--   routed to endpoints based on the health of the endpoint along with
--   configuration options that you choose, such as endpoint weights. For
--   each endpoint, you can configure weights, which are numbers that you
--   can use to specify the proportion of traffic to route to each one.
--   This can be useful, for example, to do performance testing within a
--   Region.Endpoints for custom routing accelerators are virtual private
--   cloud (VPC) subnets with one or many EC2 instances.</li>
--   </ul>
module Amazonka.GlobalAccelerator

-- | API version <tt>2018-08-08</tt> of the Amazon Global Accelerator SDK
--   configuration.
defaultService :: Service

-- | You don't have access permission.
_AccessDeniedException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The accelerator that you specified has a listener associated with it.
--   You must remove all dependent resources from an accelerator before you
--   can delete it.
_AssociatedListenerFoundException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The endpoint that you specified doesn't exist.
_EndpointAlreadyExistsException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | An argument that you specified is invalid.
_InvalidArgumentException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The listener that you specified has an endpoint group associated with
--   it. You must remove all dependent resources from a listener before you
--   can delete it.
_AssociatedEndpointGroupFoundException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The accelerator that you specified could not be disabled.
_AcceleratorNotDisabledException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | You can't use both of those options.
_ConflictException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The endpoint that you specified doesn't exist.
_EndpointNotFoundException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The listener that you specified doesn't exist.
_ListenerNotFoundException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | There isn't another item to return.
_InvalidNextTokenException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | There was an internal error for AWS Global Accelerator.
_InternalServiceErrorException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The endpoint group that you specified already exists.
_EndpointGroupAlreadyExistsException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The CIDR that you specified was not found or is incorrect.
_ByoipCidrNotFoundException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The CIDR that you specified is not valid for this action. For example,
--   the state of the CIDR might be incorrect for this action.
_IncorrectCidrStateException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The port numbers that you specified are not valid numbers or are not
--   unique for this accelerator.
_InvalidPortRangeException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The endpoint group that you specified doesn't exist.
_EndpointGroupNotFoundException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | The accelerator that you specified doesn't exist.
_AcceleratorNotFoundException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | Processing your request would cause you to exceed an AWS Global
--   Accelerator limit.
_LimitExceededException :: AsError a => Getting (First ServiceError) a ServiceError

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDenyCustomRoutingTraffic</a> smart constructor.
data DenyCustomRoutingTraffic
DenyCustomRoutingTraffic' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Natural] -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> Text -> DenyCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | Create a value of <a>DenyCustomRoutingTraffic</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationAddresses:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationAddresses</a> - A list of
--   specific Amazon EC2 instance IP addresses (destination addresses) in a
--   subnet that you want to prevent from receiving traffic. The IP
--   addresses must be a subset of the IP addresses allowed for the VPC
--   subnet associated with the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationPorts:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationPorts</a> - A list of specific
--   Amazon EC2 instance ports (destination ports) in a subnet endpoint
--   that you want to prevent from receiving traffic.
--   
--   <a>$sel:denyAllTrafficToEndpoint:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_denyAllTrafficToEndpoint</a> - Indicates
--   whether all destination IP addresses and ports for a specified VPC
--   subnet endpoint <i>cannot</i> receive traffic from a custom routing
--   accelerator. The value is TRUE or FALSE.
--   
--   When set to TRUE, <i>no</i> destinations in the custom routing VPC
--   subnet can receive traffic. Note that you cannot specify destination
--   IP addresses and ports when the value is set to TRUE.
--   
--   When set to FALSE (or not specified), you <i>must</i> specify a list
--   of destination IP addresses that cannot receive traffic. A list of
--   ports is optional. If you don't specify a list of ports, the ports
--   that can accept traffic is the same as the ports configured for the
--   endpoint group.
--   
--   The default value is FALSE.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:DenyCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>denyCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointId</a> - An ID for the endpoint.
--   For custom routing accelerators, this is the virtual private cloud
--   (VPC) subnet ID.
newDenyCustomRoutingTraffic :: Text -> Text -> DenyCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newDenyCustomRoutingTrafficResponse</a> smart
--   constructor.
data DenyCustomRoutingTrafficResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>DenyCustomRoutingTrafficResponse</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
newDenyCustomRoutingTrafficResponse :: DenyCustomRoutingTrafficResponse

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup</a> smart
--   constructor.
data CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup
CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup' :: Text -> Text -> NonEmpty CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration -> Text -> CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerArn:CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingEndpointGroup_listenerArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the listener for a custom routing endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupRegion:CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingEndpointGroup_endpointGroupRegion</a> - The AWS
--   Region where the endpoint group is located. A listener can have only
--   one endpoint group in a specific Region.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationConfigurations:CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingEndpointGroup_destinationConfigurations</a> -
--   Sets the port range and protocol for all endpoints (virtual private
--   cloud subnets) in a custom routing endpoint group to accept client
--   traffic on.
--   
--   <a>$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingEndpointGroup_idempotencyToken</a> - A unique,
--   case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the
--   idempotency—that is, the uniqueness—of the request.
newCreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup :: Text -> Text -> NonEmpty CustomRoutingDestinationConfiguration -> Text -> CreateCustomRoutingEndpointGroup

data UpdateEndpointGroup
UpdateEndpointGroup' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol -> Maybe Double -> Maybe [EndpointConfiguration] -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe [PortOverride] -> Text -> UpdateEndpointGroup

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateEndpointGroup</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:thresholdCount:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_thresholdCount</a> - The number of consecutive
--   health checks required to set the state of a healthy endpoint to
--   unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to healthy. The default
--   value is 3.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPath:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckPath</a> - If the protocol is
--   HTTP/S, then this specifies the path that is the destination for
--   health check targets. The default value is slash (/).
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds</a> - The time—10
--   seconds or 30 seconds—between each health check for an endpoint. The
--   default value is 30.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckProtocol:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol</a> - The protocol that AWS
--   Global Accelerator uses to check the health of endpoints that are part
--   of this endpoint group. The default value is TCP.
--   
--   <a>$sel:trafficDialPercentage:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage</a> - The percentage of
--   traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic is distributed to
--   other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointConfigurations:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_endpointConfigurations</a> - The list of
--   endpoint objects. A resource must be valid and active when you add it
--   as an endpoint.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPort:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_healthCheckPort</a> - The port that AWS Global
--   Accelerator uses to check the health of endpoints that are part of
--   this endpoint group. The default port is the listener port that this
--   endpoint group is associated with. If the listener port is a list of
--   ports, Global Accelerator uses the first port in the list.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portOverrides:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_portOverrides</a> - Override specific listener
--   ports used to route traffic to endpoints that are part of this
--   endpoint group. For example, you can create a port override in which
--   the listener receives user traffic on ports 80 and 443, but your
--   accelerator routes that traffic to ports 1080 and 1443, respectively,
--   on the endpoints.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Port overrides</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:UpdateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>updateEndpointGroup_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the endpoint group.
newUpdateEndpointGroup :: Text -> UpdateEndpointGroup

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateAccelerator</a> smart constructor.
data CreateAccelerator
CreateAccelerator' :: Maybe Bool -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe [Tag] -> Maybe [Text] -> Text -> Text -> CreateAccelerator

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateAccelerator</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:enabled:CreateAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createAccelerator_enabled</a> - Indicates whether an accelerator is
--   enabled. The value is true or false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, an accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:CreateAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createAccelerator_ipAddressType</a> - The value for the address
--   type must be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateAccelerator'</a>, <a>createAccelerator_tags</a> -
--   Create tags for an accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Tagging in AWS Global Accelerator</a> in
--   the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddresses:CreateAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createAccelerator_ipAddresses</a> - Optionally, if you've added
--   your own IP address pool to Global Accelerator (BYOIP), you can choose
--   IP addresses from your own pool to use for the accelerator's static IP
--   addresses when you create an accelerator. You can specify one or two
--   addresses, separated by a space. Do not include the /32 suffix.
--   
--   Only one IP address from each of your IP address ranges can be used
--   for each accelerator. If you specify only one IP address from your IP
--   address range, Global Accelerator assigns a second static IP address
--   for the accelerator from the AWS IP address pool.
--   
--   Note that you can't update IP addresses for an existing accelerator.
--   To change them, you must create a new accelerator with the new
--   addresses.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring Your Own IP Addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CreateAccelerator'</a>, <a>createAccelerator_name</a> -
--   The name of an accelerator. The name can have a maximum of 32
--   characters, must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-),
--   and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
--   
--   <a>$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createAccelerator_idempotencyToken</a> - A unique, case-sensitive
--   identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency—that is, the
--   uniqueness—of an accelerator.
newCreateAccelerator :: Text -> Text -> CreateAccelerator

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateAcceleratorResponse</a> smart constructor.

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newAllowCustomRoutingTraffic</a> smart constructor.
data AllowCustomRoutingTraffic
AllowCustomRoutingTraffic' :: Maybe [Text] -> Maybe [Natural] -> Maybe Bool -> Text -> Text -> AllowCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | Create a value of <a>AllowCustomRoutingTraffic</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationAddresses:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationAddresses</a> - A list of
--   specific Amazon EC2 instance IP addresses (destination addresses) in a
--   subnet that you want to allow to receive traffic. The IP addresses
--   must be a subset of the IP addresses that you specified for the
--   endpoint group.
--   
--   <tt>DestinationAddresses</tt> is required if
--   <tt>AllowAllTrafficToEndpoint</tt> is <tt>FALSE</tt> or is not
--   specified.
--   
--   <a>$sel:destinationPorts:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_destinationPorts</a> - A list of specific
--   Amazon EC2 instance ports (destination ports) that you want to allow
--   to receive traffic.
--   
--   <a>$sel:allowAllTrafficToEndpoint:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_allowAllTrafficToEndpoint</a> - Indicates
--   whether all destination IP addresses and ports for a specified VPC
--   subnet endpoint can receive traffic from a custom routing accelerator.
--   The value is TRUE or FALSE.
--   
--   When set to TRUE, <i>all</i> destinations in the custom routing VPC
--   subnet can receive traffic. Note that you cannot specify destination
--   IP addresses and ports when the value is set to TRUE.
--   
--   When set to FALSE (or not specified), you <i>must</i> specify a list
--   of destination IP addresses that are allowed to receive traffic. A
--   list of ports is optional. If you don't specify a list of ports, the
--   ports that can accept traffic is the same as the ports configured for
--   the endpoint group.
--   
--   The default value is FALSE.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupArn:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointGroupArn</a> - The Amazon
--   Resource Name (ARN) of the endpoint group.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointId:AllowCustomRoutingTraffic'</a>,
--   <a>allowCustomRoutingTraffic_endpointId</a> - An ID for the endpoint.
--   For custom routing accelerators, this is the virtual private cloud
--   (VPC) subnet ID.
newAllowCustomRoutingTraffic :: Text -> Text -> AllowCustomRoutingTraffic

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:enabled:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingAccelerator_enabled</a> - Indicates whether an
--   accelerator is enabled. The value is true or false. The default value
--   is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, an accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, the accelerator can be deleted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingAccelerator_ipAddressType</a> - The value for
--   the address type must be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingAccelerator_tags</a> - Create tags for an
--   accelerator.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Tagging in AWS Global Accelerator</a> in
--   the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddresses:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingAccelerator_ipAddresses</a> - Optionally, if
--   you've added your own IP address pool to Global Accelerator (BYOIP),
--   you can choose IP addresses from your own pool to use for the
--   accelerator's static IP addresses when you create an accelerator. You
--   can specify one or two addresses, separated by a space. Do not include
--   the /32 suffix.
--   
--   Only one IP address from each of your IP address ranges can be used
--   for each accelerator. If you specify only one IP address from your IP
--   address range, Global Accelerator assigns a second static IP address
--   for the accelerator from the AWS IP address pool.
--   
--   Note that you can't update IP addresses for an existing accelerator.
--   To change them, you must create a new accelerator with the new
--   addresses.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring your own IP addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingAccelerator_name</a> - The name of a custom
--   routing accelerator. The name can have a maximum of 64 characters,
--   must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-), and must not
--   begin or end with a hyphen.
--   
--   <a>$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>createCustomRoutingAccelerator_idempotencyToken</a> - A unique,
--   case-sensitive identifier that you provide to ensure the
--   idempotency—that is, the uniqueness—of the request.
newCreateCustomRoutingAccelerator :: Text -> Text -> CreateCustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateListener</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateListener
UpdateListener' :: Maybe (NonEmpty PortRange) -> Maybe Protocol -> Maybe ClientAffinity -> Text -> UpdateListener

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateListener</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:portRanges:UpdateListener'</a>,
--   <a>updateListener_portRanges</a> - The updated list of port ranges for
--   the connections from clients to the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:UpdateListener'</a>, <a>updateListener_protocol</a> -
--   The updated protocol for the connections from clients to the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientAffinity:UpdateListener'</a>,
--   <a>updateListener_clientAffinity</a> - Client affinity lets you direct
--   all requests from a user to the same endpoint, if you have stateful
--   applications, regardless of the port and protocol of the client
--   request. Client affinity gives you control over whether to always
--   route each client to the same specific endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerArn:UpdateListener'</a>,
--   <a>updateListener_listenerArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the listener to update.
newUpdateListener :: Text -> UpdateListener

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newUpdateListenerResponse</a> smart constructor.
data UpdateListenerResponse
UpdateListenerResponse' :: Maybe Listener -> Int -> UpdateListenerResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateListenerResponse</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:listener:UpdateListenerResponse'</a>,
--   <a>updateListenerResponse_listener</a> - Information for the updated

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateListener</a> smart constructor.
data CreateListener
CreateListener' :: Maybe ClientAffinity -> Text -> NonEmpty PortRange -> Protocol -> Text -> CreateListener

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateListener</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientAffinity:CreateListener'</a>,
--   <a>createListener_clientAffinity</a> - Client affinity lets you direct
--   all requests from a user to the same endpoint, if you have stateful
--   applications, regardless of the port and protocol of the client
--   request. Client affinity gives you control over whether to always
--   route each client to the same specific endpoint.
--   
--   AWS Global Accelerator uses a consistent-flow hashing algorithm to
--   choose the optimal endpoint for a connection. If client affinity is
--   <tt>NONE</tt>, Global Accelerator uses the "five-tuple" (5-tuple)
--   properties—source IP address, source port, destination IP address,
--   destination port, and protocol—to select the hash value, and then
--   chooses the best endpoint. However, with this setting, if someone uses
--   different ports to connect to Global Accelerator, their connections
--   might not be always routed to the same endpoint because the hash value
--   changes.
--   
--   If you want a given client to always be routed to the same endpoint,
--   set client affinity to <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> instead. When you use the
--   <tt>SOURCE_IP</tt> setting, Global Accelerator uses the "two-tuple"
--   (2-tuple) properties— source (client) IP address and destination IP
--   address—to select the hash value.
--   
--   The default value is <tt>NONE</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:CreateListener'</a>,
--   <a>createListener_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN)
--   of your accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portRanges:CreateListener'</a>,
--   <a>createListener_portRanges</a> - The list of port ranges to support
--   for connections from clients to your accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:protocol:CreateListener'</a>, <a>createListener_protocol</a> -
--   The protocol for connections from clients to your accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateListener'</a>,
--   <a>createListener_idempotencyToken</a> - A unique, case-sensitive
--   identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency—that is, the
--   uniqueness—of the request.
newCreateListener :: Text -> NonEmpty PortRange -> Protocol -> Text -> CreateListener

-- | <i>See:</i> <a>newCreateListenerResponse</a> smart constructor.
data CreateListenerResponse
CreateListenerResponse' :: Maybe Listener -> Int -> CreateListenerResponse

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateListenerResponse</a> with all optional

--   fields.

--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

data CreateEndpointGroup
CreateEndpointGroup' :: Maybe Natural -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe HealthCheckProtocol -> Maybe Double -> Maybe [EndpointConfiguration] -> Maybe Natural -> Maybe [PortOverride] -> Text -> Text -> Text -> CreateEndpointGroup

-- | Create a value of <a>CreateEndpointGroup</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:thresholdCount:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_thresholdCount</a> - The number of consecutive
--   health checks required to set the state of a healthy endpoint to
--   unhealthy, or to set an unhealthy endpoint to healthy. The default
--   value is 3.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPath:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_healthCheckPath</a> - If the protocol is
--   HTTP/S, then this specifies the path that is the destination for
--   health check targets. The default value is slash (/).
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckIntervalSeconds:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_healthCheckIntervalSeconds</a> - The time—10
--   seconds or 30 seconds—between each health check for an endpoint. The
--   default value is 30.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckProtocol:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_healthCheckProtocol</a> - The protocol that AWS
--   Global Accelerator uses to check the health of endpoints that are part
--   of this endpoint group. The default value is TCP.
--   
--   <a>$sel:trafficDialPercentage:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_trafficDialPercentage</a> - The percentage of
--   traffic to send to an AWS Region. Additional traffic is distributed to
--   other endpoint groups for this listener.
--   
--   Use this action to increase (dial up) or decrease (dial down) traffic
--   to a specific Region. The percentage is applied to the traffic that
--   would otherwise have been routed to the Region based on optimal
--   routing.
--   
--   The default value is 100.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointConfigurations:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_endpointConfigurations</a> - The list of
--   endpoint objects.
--   
--   <a>$sel:healthCheckPort:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_healthCheckPort</a> - The port that AWS Global
--   Accelerator uses to check the health of endpoints that are part of
--   this endpoint group. The default port is the listener port that this
--   endpoint group is associated with. If listener port is a list of
--   ports, Global Accelerator uses the first port in the list.
--   
--   <a>$sel:portOverrides:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_portOverrides</a> - Override specific listener
--   ports used to route traffic to endpoints that are part of this
--   endpoint group. For example, you can create a port override in which
--   the listener receives user traffic on ports 80 and 443, but your
--   accelerator routes that traffic to ports 1080 and 1443, respectively,
--   on the endpoints.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Port overrides</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:listenerArn:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_listenerArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the listener.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endpointGroupRegion:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_endpointGroupRegion</a> - The AWS Region where
--   the endpoint group is located. A listener can have only one endpoint
--   group in a specific Region.
--   
--   <a>$sel:idempotencyToken:CreateEndpointGroup'</a>,
--   <a>createEndpointGroup_idempotencyToken</a> - A unique, case-sensitive
--   identifier that you provide to ensure the idempotency—that is, the
--   uniqueness—of the request.
newCreateEndpointGroup :: Text -> Text -> Text -> CreateEndpointGroup

--   <a>$sel:resourceArn:TagResource'</a>, <a>tagResource_resourceArn</a> -
--   The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Global Accelerator resource to
--   add tags to. An ARN uniquely identifies a resource.
--   
--   <a>$sel:tags:TagResource'</a>, <a>tagResource_tags</a> - The tags to
--   add to a resource. A tag consists of a key and a value that you
--   define.
newTagResource :: Text -> TagResource

-- | Create a value of <a>UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes</a> with

--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Prefix</a> -
--   Update the prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the
--   flow logs. Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is
--   <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   DOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsEnabled:UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled</a> -
--   Update whether flow logs are enabled. The default value is false. If
--   the value is true, <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsS3Bucket:UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Bucket</a> - The
--   name of the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is required
--   if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must exist
--   and have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator permission
--   to write to the bucket.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:UpdateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>updateCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_acceleratorArn</a> - The
--   Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator to update

newtype AcceleratorStatus
AcceleratorStatus' :: Text -> AcceleratorStatus
[fromAcceleratorStatus] :: AcceleratorStatus -> Text
pattern AcceleratorStatus_DEPLOYED :: AcceleratorStatus
pattern AcceleratorStatus_IN_PROGRESS :: AcceleratorStatus
newtype ByoipCidrState
ByoipCidrState' :: Text -> ByoipCidrState
[fromByoipCidrState] :: ByoipCidrState -> Text
pattern ByoipCidrState_ADVERTISING :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_DEPROVISIONED :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_FAILED_ADVERTISING :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_FAILED_DEPROVISION :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_FAILED_PROVISION :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_FAILED_WITHDRAW :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_PENDING_ADVERTISING :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_PENDING_DEPROVISIONING :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_PENDING_PROVISIONING :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_PENDING_WITHDRAWING :: ByoipCidrState
pattern ByoipCidrState_READY :: ByoipCidrState
newtype ClientAffinity
ClientAffinity' :: Text -> ClientAffinity
[fromClientAffinity] :: ClientAffinity -> Text
pattern ClientAffinity_NONE :: ClientAffinity
pattern ClientAffinity_SOURCE_IP :: ClientAffinity
newtype CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus
CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus' :: Text -> CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus
[fromCustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus] :: CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus -> Text
pattern CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus_DEPLOYED :: CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus
pattern CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus_IN_PROGRESS :: CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus
newtype CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState
CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState' :: Text -> CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState
[fromCustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState] :: CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState -> Text
pattern CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState_ALLOW :: CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState
pattern CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState_DENY :: CustomRoutingDestinationTrafficState
newtype CustomRoutingProtocol
CustomRoutingProtocol' :: Text -> CustomRoutingProtocol
[fromCustomRoutingProtocol] :: CustomRoutingProtocol -> Text
pattern CustomRoutingProtocol_TCP :: CustomRoutingProtocol
pattern CustomRoutingProtocol_UDP :: CustomRoutingProtocol
newtype HealthCheckProtocol
HealthCheckProtocol' :: Text -> HealthCheckProtocol
[fromHealthCheckProtocol] :: HealthCheckProtocol -> Text
pattern HealthCheckProtocol_HTTP :: HealthCheckProtocol
pattern HealthCheckProtocol_HTTPS :: HealthCheckProtocol
pattern HealthCheckProtocol_TCP :: HealthCheckProtocol
newtype HealthState
HealthState' :: Text -> HealthState
[fromHealthState] :: HealthState -> Text
pattern HealthState_HEALTHY :: HealthState
pattern HealthState_INITIAL :: HealthState
pattern HealthState_UNHEALTHY :: HealthState
newtype IpAddressType
IpAddressType' :: Text -> IpAddressType
[fromIpAddressType] :: IpAddressType -> Text
pattern IpAddressType_IPV4 :: IpAddressType
newtype Protocol
Protocol' :: Text -> Protocol
[fromProtocol] :: Protocol -> Text
pattern Protocol_TCP :: Protocol
pattern Protocol_UDP :: Protocol

-- | An accelerator is a complex type that includes one or more listeners
--   that process inbound connections and then direct traffic to one or
--   more endpoint groups, each of which includes endpoints, such as load
--   balancers.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAccelerator</a> smart constructor.
data Accelerator
Accelerator' :: Maybe AcceleratorStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [IpSet] -> Maybe Text -> Accelerator

-- | Create a value of <a>Accelerator</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_status</a> - Describes
--   the deployment status of the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:Accelerator'</a>,
--   <a>accelerator_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of
--   the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enabled:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_enabled</a> -
--   Indicates whether the accelerator is enabled. The value is true or
--   false. The default value is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, accelerator can be deleted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdTime:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_createdTime</a> -
--   The date and time that the accelerator was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastModifiedTime:Accelerator'</a>,
--   <a>accelerator_lastModifiedTime</a> - The date and time that the
--   accelerator was last modified.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:Accelerator'</a>,
--   <a>accelerator_ipAddressType</a> - The value for the address type must
--   be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_name</a> - The name of
--   the accelerator. The name must contain only alphanumeric characters or
--   hyphens (-), and must not begin or end with a hyphen.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipSets:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_ipSets</a> - The
--   static IP addresses that Global Accelerator associates with the
--   accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsName:Accelerator'</a>, <a>accelerator_dnsName</a> - The
--   Domain Name System (DNS) name that Global Accelerator creates that
--   points to your accelerator's static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
newAccelerator :: Accelerator

-- | Attributes of an accelerator.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newAcceleratorAttributes</a> smart constructor.
data AcceleratorAttributes
AcceleratorAttributes' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> AcceleratorAttributes

-- | Create a value of <a>AcceleratorAttributes</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsS3Prefix:AcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>acceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Prefix</a> - The prefix for the
--   location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is
--   required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   s3-bucket_name//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsEnabled:AcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>acceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled</a> - Indicates whether flow
--   logs are enabled. The default value is false. If the value is true,
--   <tt>FlowLogsS3Bucket</tt> and <tt>FlowLogsS3Prefix</tt> must be
--   specified.
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Flow Logs</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsS3Bucket:AcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>acceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Bucket</a> - The name of the Amazon
--   S3 bucket for the flow logs. Attribute is required if
--   <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>. The bucket must exist and
--   have a bucket policy that grants AWS Global Accelerator permission to
--   write to the bucket.
newAcceleratorAttributes :: AcceleratorAttributes

-- | Information about an IP address range that is provisioned for use with
--   your AWS resources through bring your own IP address (BYOIP).
--   
--   The following describes each BYOIP <tt>State</tt> that your IP address
--   range can be in.
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><b>PENDING_PROVISIONING</b> — You’ve submitted a request to
--   provision an IP address range but it is not yet provisioned with AWS
--   Global Accelerator.</li>
--   <li><b>READY</b> — The address range is provisioned with AWS Global
--   Accelerator and can be advertised.</li>
--   <li><b>PENDING_ADVERTISING</b> — You’ve submitted a request for AWS
--   Global Accelerator to advertise an address range but it is not yet
--   being advertised.</li>
--   <li><b>ADVERTISING</b> — The address range is being advertised by AWS
--   Global Accelerator.</li>
--   <li><b>PENDING_WITHDRAWING</b> — You’ve submitted a request to
--   withdraw an address range from being advertised but it is still being
--   advertised by AWS Global Accelerator.</li>
--   <li><b>PENDING_DEPROVISIONING</b> — You’ve submitted a request to
--   deprovision an address range from AWS Global Accelerator but it is
--   still provisioned.</li>
--   <li><b>DEPROVISIONED</b> — The address range is deprovisioned from AWS
--   Global Accelerator.</li>
--   <li><b>FAILED_PROVISION</b> — The request to provision the address
--   range from AWS Global Accelerator was not successful. Please make sure
--   that you provide all of the correct information, and try again. If the
--   request fails a second time, contact AWS support.</li>
--   <li><b>FAILED_ADVERTISING</b> — The request for AWS Global Accelerator
--   to advertise the address range was not successful. Please make sure
--   that you provide all of the correct information, and try again. If the
--   request fails a second time, contact AWS support.</li>
--   <li><b>FAILED_WITHDRAW</b> — The request to withdraw the address range
--   from advertising by AWS Global Accelerator was not successful. Please
--   make sure that you provide all of the correct information, and try
--   again. If the request fails a second time, contact AWS support.</li>
--   <li><b>FAILED_DEPROVISION</b> — The request to deprovision the address
--   range from AWS Global Accelerator was not successful. Please make sure
--   that you provide all of the correct information, and try again. If the
--   request fails a second time, contact AWS support.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newByoipCidr</a> smart constructor.
data ByoipCidr
ByoipCidr' :: Maybe ByoipCidrState -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [ByoipCidrEvent] -> ByoipCidr

-- | Create a value of <a>ByoipCidr</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:state:ByoipCidr'</a>, <a>byoipCidr_state</a> - The state of
--   the address pool.
--   
--   <a>$sel:cidr:ByoipCidr'</a>, <a>byoipCidr_cidr</a> - The address
--   range, in CIDR notation.
--   
--   <a>$sel:events:ByoipCidr'</a>, <a>byoipCidr_events</a> - A history of
--   status changes for an IP address range that you bring to AWS Global
--   Accelerator through bring your own IP address (BYOIP).
newByoipCidr :: ByoipCidr

-- | A complex type that contains a <tt>Message</tt> and a
--   <tt>Timestamp</tt> value for changes that you make in the status an IP
--   address range that you bring to AWS Global Accelerator through bring
--   your own IP address (BYOIP).
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newByoipCidrEvent</a> smart constructor.
data ByoipCidrEvent
ByoipCidrEvent' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe POSIX -> ByoipCidrEvent

-- | Create a value of <a>ByoipCidrEvent</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:message:ByoipCidrEvent'</a>, <a>byoipCidrEvent_message</a> - A
--   string that contains an <tt>Event</tt> message describing changes that
--   you make in the status of an IP address range that you bring to AWS
--   Global Accelerator through bring your own IP address (BYOIP).
--   
--   <a>$sel:timestamp:ByoipCidrEvent'</a>, <a>byoipCidrEvent_timestamp</a>
--   - A timestamp when you make a status change for an IP address range
--   that you bring to AWS Global Accelerator through bring your own IP
--   address (BYOIP).
newByoipCidrEvent :: ByoipCidrEvent

-- | Provides authorization for Amazon to bring a specific IP address range
--   to a specific AWS account using bring your own IP addresses (BYOIP).
--   
--   For more information, see <a>Bring Your Own IP Addresses (BYOIP)</a>
--   in the <i>AWS Global Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCidrAuthorizationContext</a> smart constructor.
data CidrAuthorizationContext
CidrAuthorizationContext' :: Text -> Text -> CidrAuthorizationContext

-- | Create a value of <a>CidrAuthorizationContext</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:message:CidrAuthorizationContext'</a>,
--   <a>cidrAuthorizationContext_message</a> - The plain-text authorization
--   message for the prefix and account.
--   
--   <a>$sel:signature:CidrAuthorizationContext'</a>,
--   <a>cidrAuthorizationContext_signature</a> - The signed authorization
--   message for the prefix and account.
newCidrAuthorizationContext :: Text -> Text -> CidrAuthorizationContext

-- | Attributes of a custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCustomRoutingAccelerator</a> smart constructor.
data CustomRoutingAccelerator
CustomRoutingAccelerator' :: Maybe CustomRoutingAcceleratorStatus -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe POSIX -> Maybe IpAddressType -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [IpSet] -> Maybe Text -> CustomRoutingAccelerator

-- | Create a value of <a>CustomRoutingAccelerator</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:status:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_status</a> - Describes the deployment
--   status of the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:acceleratorArn:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_acceleratorArn</a> - The Amazon Resource
--   Name (ARN) of the custom routing accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:enabled:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_enabled</a> - Indicates whether the
--   accelerator is enabled. The value is true or false. The default value
--   is true.
--   
--   If the value is set to true, the accelerator cannot be deleted. If set
--   to false, accelerator can be deleted.
--   
--   <a>$sel:createdTime:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_createdTime</a> - The date and time that
--   the accelerator was created.
--   
--   <a>$sel:lastModifiedTime:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_lastModifiedTime</a> - The date and time
--   that the accelerator was last modified.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipAddressType:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_ipAddressType</a> - The value for the
--   address type must be IPv4.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_name</a> - The name of the accelerator.
--   The name must contain only alphanumeric characters or hyphens (-), and
--   must not begin or end with a hyphen.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ipSets:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_ipSets</a> - The static IP addresses that
--   Global Accelerator associates with the accelerator.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dnsName:CustomRoutingAccelerator'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAccelerator_dnsName</a> - The Domain Name System (DNS)
--   name that Global Accelerator creates that points to your accelerator's
--   static IP addresses.
--   
--   The naming convention for the DNS name is the following: A lowercase
--   letter a, followed by a 16-bit random hex string, followed by
--   .awsglobalaccelerator.com. For example:
--   a1234567890abcdef.awsglobalaccelerator.com.
--   
--   For more information about the default DNS name, see <a>Support for
--   DNS Addressing in Global Accelerator</a> in the <i>AWS Global
--   Accelerator Developer Guide</i>.
newCustomRoutingAccelerator :: CustomRoutingAccelerator

--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newCustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes</a> smart
--   constructor.
data CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes
CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Bool -> Maybe Text -> CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes

-- | Create a value of <a>CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes</a> with all
--   optional fields omitted.

--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsS3Prefix:CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsS3Prefix</a> - The
--   prefix for the location in the Amazon S3 bucket for the flow logs.
--   Attribute is required if <tt>FlowLogsEnabled</tt> is <tt>true</tt>.
--   
--   If you don’t specify a prefix, the flow logs are stored in the root of
--   the bucket. If you specify slash (/) for the S3 bucket prefix, the log
--   file bucket folder structure will include a double slash (//), like
--   the following:
--   
--   DOC-EXAMPLE-BUCKET//AWSLogs/aws_account_id
--   
--   <a>$sel:flowLogsEnabled:CustomRoutingAcceleratorAttributes'</a>,
--   <a>customRoutingAcceleratorAttributes_flowLogsEnabled</a> - Indicates
